column2: Witching Hour: CNBC Explains
column5: Witching hour\xe2\x80\x94though it may sound like a Halloween promotion at a local bar\xe2\x80\x94 describes three important time periods for investors and the markets. So what are witching hours and how do they impact investments? CNBC explains.

column2: Cupcake Killer: How Cake Pops Became the Next Big Trend
column5: By day, Angie Dudley is a mild-mannered graphic designer who lives near Atlanta. In her off hours, she\xe2\x80\x99s Bakerella, cake-pop maker, blogger, and culinary star to home bakers around the world.As Bakerella, Dudley started a mini-revolution in baking after one of her cake-on-a-stick creations went viral and she was invited on Martha Stewart\xe2\x80\x99s TV show in April 2008. Now, about four years after Dudley first wrote about how to combine cake crumbs and frosting into petite treats, her blog gets nearly 3.8 million page views a month and she\xe2\x80\x99s a New York Times best-selling cookbook author. And the bite-sized morsels of cake and frosting, for which she is often credited with popularizing, have inspired at least one cake-pop-making appliance, the Babycakes cake-pop maker. It\xe2\x80\x99s expected to be a popular gift for many home cooks this holiday season.

column2: FedEx Will Outperform for Years: Analyst
column5: Factors such as leverage, emerging market growth, and the consumer shift to e-commerce will keep FedEx going strong for the next few years, says transportation services analyst for Morgan Keegan, Arthur Hatfield. Hatfield's comparison to competitor United Parcel Service, which is also performing well during the holiday shipping season, shows why FedEx might remain on top.

column2: CNBC's Winners & Losers of the Financial World in 2011
column5: As we seek your input on the 2011 winners and losers candidates, you\xe2\x80\x99ll note that we have few repeats from last year's bunch and only one who also made our inaugural list in 2009. That\xe2\x80\x99s Fed Chairman BenBernanke, who continues to loom over the economy. GOP Rep.John Boehner (now House Speaker), President Barack Obama, and the American taxpayer are back from 2010. Carol Bartz is back from 2009 \xe2\x80\x94 she lasted slightly longer at Yahoo than we expected.Boehner is back because he\xe2\x80\x99s played a leading role in the debate over the shape of government. He's been involved in battles over the deficit with the Democrats and Obama, whom we also include for that reason. Organizations (Occupy Wall Street, NBA/NFL) made our list, as has a celebrity (Justin Bieber). Some of these people and companies are also the stuff of CNBC's predictions for the year ahead. As in past years, the difference between a winner and a loser can be in the eye of the beholder \xe2\x80\x94 or voter. It's a fine line. You have until December 21 to vote on the candidates for 2011. We\xe2\x80\x99ll bring you the results the next day. So click ahead to see all the candidates and to vote on them.

column2: Crisis Threatens to Increase Protectionism: WTO
column5: The economic crisis threatens to increase protectionism as governments think more on a national than an international level, Pascal Lamy, Director General of the World Trade Organization (WTO) told CNBC Thursday.

column2: How to Trade a European Debt Downgrade
column5: Traders have been bracing for sovereign rating cuts in Europe ever since Standard & Poor's issued a warning. Here's what to do.Credit-rating cuts are never good for countries, but when the real stalwarts get hit, it hurts more. That's why investors are bracing themselves after Standard & Poor's warned that Germany and France could face downgrades. "We've been waiting all week to see if S&P downgrades," says Andrew Busch, global currency and public policy strategist for BMO Capital. "They specifically said Germany and France, and I\xc2\xa0 think that's what caught everybody by surprise."

column2: Europe Increasingly Choking Off Hopes of Santa Rally
column5: The negativity that\xe2\x80\x99s driving the euro lower could keep pressure on stocks and commodities prices Thursday.

column2: Obama\xe2\x80\x99s Clean-Energy Obsession May Hurt Blue Collars
column5: The payroll-tax-cut debate is not really about the payroll tax, which is a very weak-kneed economic stimulant and a lackluster job creator because of its temporary nature. Without permanent incentives at lower tax rates, these rebates don\xe2\x80\x99t do anything for growth and jobs.

column2: Lines Are Drawn on Legislation Against Piracy
column5: Type \xe2\x80\x9cdownload movies for free\xe2\x80\x9d into Google, and up pops links to sites like the Pirate Bay, directing users to free copies of just about any entertainment\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 \xe2\x80\x94 the latest \xe2\x80\x9cTwilight\xe2\x80\x9d installment, this week\xe2\x80\x99s episode of \xe2\x80\x9cWhitney,\xe2\x80\x9d the complete recordings of the Red Hot Chili Peppers.

column2: Europe Wakes Up to Monetary Contraction
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: The news that European banks will now be able to borrow euros for three-year terms by posting a broad array of collateral is the best sign so far the European Central Bank is recognizing that the continent is experiencing an extreme monetary contraction.

column2: Michael Kors: Investors Looking Down a Long Runway
column5: You may know him as the judge from Project Runway or you may be fortunate enough to afford one of his timeless $2,000 dresses.

column2: Newest Tests Show It is Becoming Safer to Drive
column3: Behind the Wheel with Phil Lebeau
column5: In the last week, we\xe2\x80\x99ve seen two reports that paint a very clear picture. For millions of Americans, driving has become safer and their odds of surviving a horrific crash have improved dramatically. The latest report came out early this morning from the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety. In its annual crash test report, the IIHS gave a record number of new models a top safety rating. With 115 out of 180 2012 models performing well in a battery of crash tests, the IIHS report is proof new technology and changes in design are improving the safety of our cars, trucks and SUV\xe2\x80\x99s.

column2: Why Gold Prices Are Falling Again
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: Investors who bought gold as a hedge against the crisis in Europe may be surprised that the price of gold is falling so rapidly. Shouldn\xe2\x80\x99t the prospect of concerted action by central banks to stem a crisis in Europe send gold soaring?

column2: Reading the Strong Philly Fed Data
column5: December Philly Fed continues trend of better economic news. Current manufacturing activity was positive for the third consecutive month and increased from 3.6 in November to 10.3 (anything over 0 indicates growth). The percentage of firms reporting increases in activity (25 percent) exceeded the percentage reporting decreases (15 percent). The index for current new orders also increased. This is a positive, because it implies that business spending may begin rising \xe2\x80\x94 that means higher factory orders and capital goods orders.

column2: Zynga IPO Offers Plenty of Upside, Analyst Says
column5: One \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d analyst sounded positive on the highly anticipated Zynga IPO, citing the company\xe2\x80\x99s potential for growth. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s currently the leader in the social gaming space. It has 54 million daily active users, which is more than the next 14 game developers combined,\xe2\x80\x9d said Stephanie Chang, research analyst at Renaissance Capital. Zynga, which priced shares at $10, will hold its initial public offering Friday under the symbol ZYNG. The initial share price will give the company a valuation of $7 billion.

column2: Is the BlackBerry 10 Delay a \xe2\x80\x98Death Knell\xe2\x80\x99 for RIM?
column5: Research In Motion has delayed the release of its BlackBerry 10 smartphone device until the latter part of 2012, company executives said on its earnings conference call after Thursday\xe2\x80\x99s closing bell. The news took the \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d traders by surprise and options trader Mike Khouw went so far as to call it a \xe2\x80\x9cdeath knell\xe2\x80\x9d for the troubled technology company.

column2: Chertoff Warns of Cyber Threats to Economy
column5: Never mind trouble with the euro or a slowdown in global growth. Cyber attacks might be one of the largest threats to the U.S. economy, former Homeland Security chief Michael Chertoff said Thursday on \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cMembers of Congress on both sides of the aisle are now dumbfounded at the amount of intellectual property that is being stolen from our country,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat strikes directly at the ability to create jobs and be competitive internationally.\xe2\x80\x9d Chertoff said he expects legislation next year to combat the growing threat.

column2: Long-Shot Trades in an Uncertain Market
column5: Yesterday's difficult market caused investors to take long-shot trades with low probability of success, but also limited risk. One such trade occurred in Adtran as a block of 1,500 May 29 calls were bought for $2.93 and an equal number of contracts were sold each in the May 35 calls and May 24 puts for 92 cents and $1.81, respectively, according to OptionMonster's real-time tracking systems.

column2: New Foreclosure Wave is Coming
column5: Despite a seasonal slowdown in overall foreclosure activity, and a process still bogged down and backed up by the "robo-signing" processing scandal, the U.S real estate market is about to be hit by another surge of bank repossessions, according to a new report from the online foreclosure sale site RealtyTrac. As banks resubmit millions of documents and courts begin hearing cases again, the backlog of over four million delinquent loans will start surging through the pipeline again. "November\xe2\x80\x99s numbers suggest a new set of incoming foreclosure waves, many of which may roll into the market as REOs [bank repossessions] or short sales sometime early next year,\xe2\x80\x9d said James Saccacio, co-founder of RealtyTrac. \xe2\x80\x9cOverall foreclosure activity is down 14 percent from a year ago, the smallest annual decrease over the past 12 months, and some bellwether states such as California, Arizona and Massachusetts actually posted year-over-year increases in foreclosure activity in November." Foreclosure auctions, where the property is sold at the courthouse either to an investor or in most cases back to the bank, reached a nine-month high in November, which corresponds to a recent surge in default notices, the first stage in the foreclosure process, back in August. Troubled borrowers will get a reprieve over the holidays, as mortgage giant Fannie Mae says they will not evict anyone until after the new year. A spokeswoman, however, stressed that foreclosure processing would continue through the holidays, so as not to slow the system down any more than it already is. Nevada is still in the number one spot nationally for its foreclosure rate, despite artificially low activity caused by a new state law that changes the process, requiring more documentation. It has held that dubious honor for 59 straight months. Both Georgia and Utah saw substantial monthly increases in their foreclosure rates, lifting them into the nation's top five in November. Nine out of the nation\xe2\x80\x99s 10 highest foreclosure rates among metropolitan areas with a population of 200,000 or more were in California, according to RealtyTrac, with just Las Vegas making its way into the number six spot.

column2: Euro Steadies, Swiss Franc Jumps, Dollar's on a Roll
column5: Spain's bond sale reassures but risk aversion is high - it's time for your FX Fix.The euro selloff paused after a decent Spanish bond auction. [Reuters]The Swiss franc jumped against the euro after the Swiss National Bank left its target floor rate unchanged. [WSJ]Investors who had exited the euro after its rally in October are starting to reload negative positions, traders said. [WSJ]The dollar index is near its 2011 high, thanks to worries about Europe and general risk aversion. [fxstreet.com]The Norwegian krone approached its lowest level against the dollar in 2011 after the central bank cut interest rates 50 basis points. [forexyard.com]Risk aversion sparked by the crisis in Europe sent the Australian and New Zealand dollars lower. column2: Pros Trade Research In Motion Earnings
column5: Research In Motion delivered quarterly earnings results on Thursday that beat expectations on the bottom-line, but gave a gloomy outlook going forward. As the BlackBerry maker\xe2\x80\x99s stock fell sharply in after-hours trading, the \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d traders debated whether RIMM is worth buying.To trader Guy Adami, there may be an opportunity to buy RIMM  on Friday, but only as a trade.

column2: Currency Decoupling Ahead
column5: The euro has been trading in tandem with key commodity currencies, but that could change - and create trading opportunities.Ever since the financial crisis, the euro  has been trading almost in lockstep with the Canadian dollar,  the Australian dollar, and the New Zealand dollar. \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Nick Bennenbroek and Vassili Serebriakov, strategists at Wells Fargo, say it has been most pronounced when market conditions are extreme - either stress is high, or the Federal Reserve is aggressively easing. "For 2012, however, our base case is that financial market conditions will move away from these extremes," the strategists wrote in a note to clients. And they expect the euro to move away from the commodity currencies at the same time. How do you trade this? Bennenbroek and Serebriakov argue that the euro is going to move closer to being a 'funding' currency - a currency investors sell in order to buy a higher yielding one. This would mean the euro would soften against Aussie, the kiwi, and so on. "Should the European Central Bank continue to cut rates and otherwise ease liquidity, and considering the euro zone's relatively poor economic outlook, there may be increased willingness by market participants in 2012 to fund in euros, while investing in higher yielding commodity and emerging currencies," they say. Bennenbroek and Serebriakov expect the euro to weaken significantly, to 1.20 against the dollar, in 2012 - and they expect the three big commodity currencies to outperform the buck. column2: Raymond James: Our Best Picks May Double in 2012
column5: Raymond James, an investment bank with $271 billion in client assets, said its best stock selections, which include Nvidia, may double in the next year.The bank, more known for owning the naming rights to the National Football League's Tampa Bay Buccaneers football stadium in Florida, has had a list of stock ideas that has outperformed larger rivals and benchmarks for more than a decade.

column2: VC Survey: Investment Down, Obama Up in 2012
column5: It could be an uneasy start to the new year in the venture capital world. But for President Obama, life could be good.A survey conducted by the National Venture Capital Association and Dow Jones VentureSource reveals that venture capitalists and CEOs, while still somewhat optimistic about the U.S. economy, are less certain about how much it will improve in the coming year. But Obama doesn\xe2\x80\x99t suffer from their cautious outlook. According to the sixth annual survey, which polled more than 500 VC professionals and CEOs of venture-backed U.S. companies, VCs and CEOs predict that it will be Mitt Romney vs. Obama come fall, with Obama the eventual winner by a nose.

column2: Retail Investors Should Bide Time on IPOs
column5: The initial public offering market has not been kind to retail investors over the past year. The year-to-date total return from the issue price is a drop of 5.7 percent against a decline of 1.3 percent for the Nasdaq Composite Index.Most retail investors can't get in on these companies until they are trading publicly and by then the company has already seen its increase in value and the next step is down.

column2: Will Zynga Be Able to Keep Growing?
column5: Although social game developer Zynga's IPO was widely expected to do well Friday on its market debut, the stock quickly fell below its initial public offering price as many analysts are cautious about the company\xe2\x80\x99s long-term prospects.

column2: Beijing Imposes New Rules on Social Networking Sites
column5: BEIJING \xe2\x80\x94 Officials announced new rules on Friday aimed at controlling the way Chinese Internet users post messages on social networking sites that have posed challenges to the Chinese Communist Party\xe2\x80\x99s propaganda machinery.

column2: Euro Gets a Short Term Lift, Dollar's Set to Dip
column5: Euro shorts take cover and Indonesia gets a ratings boost - it's time for your FX Fix.The euro rose in Asian trading, but traders said it reflected covering of short positions. [WSJ]With risk appetite improving, commodity currencies like the Canadian, Australian, and New Zealand dollars rose. [FT]Traders are unwinding bets on risk aversion, and the dollar could be poised to weaken. [dailyfx.com]The Chinese yuan hit a record high against the dollar on suspicion that the central bank orchestrated intervention. [CNBC] Fitch raised Indonesia's credit rating to investment grade, on par with India, for the first time since 1997, earlier than expected. Moody's and Standard & Poor's may follow. column2: As Exhausted Money Managers Cash Out, S&P Should Rise
column5: On Friday investors were trying to determine if the stock market would make peace with the woes of Europe \xe2\x80\x93 at least through the end of the year.Even as the Dow pared gains and traded into negative territory, the Fast Money traders said as of Monday - after expirations - the path of least resistance is now higher. \xe2\x80\x9cMoney managers are exhausted,\xe2\x80\x9d explains trader JJ Kinahan. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is the toughest year I can ever remember and money managers remain unsure what lies ahead." Kinahan goes on to say, money pros are eager for a two week break, they just want to begin the holiday.\xe2\x80\x9cAnd as a result, they\xe2\x80\x99re just parking money in bonds.\xe2\x80\x9dAs big money takes a rest, Kinahan expects volumes to be very light over the next two weeks, and because of light volumes he\xe2\x80\x99s looking for the market to rally into year\xe2\x80\x99s end. \xe2\x80\x9cNever sell a dull market,\xe2\x80\x9d he counsels. "Into the end of the year I'm looking for the market to go higher." Not only does Kinahan expect to see short covering as pros move to the sidelines but he also thinks investor will begin to establish new longs over the next few weeks. Both Pete and Jon Najarian share the view. They point to action in the Vix as confirmation. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Vix is down sharply," says Jon. \xe2\x80\x9cThe fear factor is coming out of the market.\xe2\x80\x9dFundamental catalysts seem to support the thesis. Data this week showed jobless claims fell to a 3-1/2-year low last week and factory activity in parts of the U.S. Northeast picked up in December.Trader Steve Grasso doesn't agree. "I'm skeptical," he says, "I'd hide out in utilities."______________________________________________________Got something to to say? column2: What Cramer\xe2\x80\x99s Watching Next Week
column5: What follows is Cramer's "Game Plan" for the week of Monday, Dec. 19.Monday, Dec. 19

column2: 2011 Top S&P Stocks: No. 11 Ross Stores
column5: Ross Stores rang up more than a 15 percent boost in its share price year to date, landing it at No. 11 in the top-performing S&P stocks of 2011. ROST shares traded in the $47 range Friday, near its 52-week low of $46.30. The stock\xe2\x80\x99s high within the same period was $95.24, and it had EPS of $2.70.

column2: ADP, Paychex Stocks to Benefit from Improved Employment
column5: It might be hard to imagine, but recent data indicates the U.S.\xe2\x80\x99s employment picture is improving, which Cramer said is good news for payroll processors ADP and Paychex.Given the choice of either stock, though, he\xe2\x80\x99d pick Paychex  because it sports a juicy 4.3 percent dividend yield. With that kind of yield, Cramer said the stock is basically paying the investor to wait until hiring accelerates and the overall economy improves.When compared to ADP , Paychex is also more levered to small businesses, which tend to do most of the new hiring. Eight-two percent of its clients have 19 employees or less, Cramer said. ADP tends to have larger clients.Paychex is also 100 percent domestic, so it\xe2\x80\x99s not bogged down by Europe\xe2\x80\x99s debt crisis. ADP, on the other hand, gets 13 percent of its sales from Europe.Both stocks trade at 18 times next year\xe2\x80\x99s earnings with a 10 percent long-term growth rate, but Paychex pays a 4.3 percent dividend yield while ADP yields a 3.1 percent.

column2: Why Zynga\xe2\x80\x99s IPO Fell Flat
column5: Zynga\xe2\x80\x99slong-anticipated IPO did not benefit from the same first-day bumps that LinkedIn  and Groupon soaring higher earlier this year. The social gaming company raised $1 billion\xe2\x80\x94issuing 100 million shares at $10 a share \xe2\x80\x93 making it the largest Internet-related IPO since Google\xe2\x80\x99s  $1.4 billion offering back in 2004. The $10 price was at the upper end of the $8.50-$10 range, valuing the company at around $7 billion, $8.9 billion including unexercised options and warrants.

column2: Macy's CEO: We're Having the Best 2 Years in a Decade
column5: There's a bull market in the best run American retailers right now, \xe2\x80\x9cMad Money\xe2\x80\x9d host Jim Cramer said Thursday. Just look at Cramer fave Macy\xe2\x80\x99s, which isup 24 percent year-to-date. \xe2\x80\x9cMacy\xe2\x80\x99s  is now barely a point and a half off it\xe2\x80\x99s 52-week high,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, \xe2\x80\x9cin part because the American consumer is alive and well [and] spending like mad, but also because Macy\xe2\x80\x99s has a phenomenal management\xe2\x80\x94a team that understands how to entice shoppers into the stores and get them to buy things.\xe2\x80\x9dThe company recently posted \xe2\x80\x9csuperb\xe2\x80\x9d same-store sales growth for November, beating analysts\xe2\x80\x99 expectations with a 4.8 percent increase. That\xe2\x80\x99s on top of its \xe2\x80\x9cfabulous\xe2\x80\x9d Black Friday numbers and the strong quarter it reported back in November. "We're having the best years, in fact back-to-back two years, in a decade, so things are going very, very well," Macy's Chairman and CEO Terry Lundgren told Cramer. And if the weather turns cold, it would be an extra boost for the retailer.To see Cramer's full interview with Lundgren, watch the video. Call Cramer: 1-800-743-CNBCQuestions for Cramer? Questions, comments, suggestions for the Mad Money website? madcap@cnbc.com

column2: \xe2\x80\x98Raging Bull' Market Is Set to Begin in 12-18 Months: Strategist
column5: A decade of zero price gains, two busted bubbles, and successive credit crises have left stock investors as disillusioned as they were at the end of the 1970s, but that could set the stage for a multi-year bull market, says Tobias Levkovich, chief U.S. equity strategist at Citi Investment Research.

column2: Deutsche Bank Puts $2.6 Billion Price Tag on Unit
column5: Deutsche Bank has launched the sale of its global asset management business following a strategic review, putting a price tag of about 2 billion euros ($2.6 billion) on it.

column2: Euro Weakened; US Stocks Dip
column5: The euro has weakened as Fitch has placed Belgium, Spain, Slovenia, Italy Ireland and Cyprus on rating watch negative, but the markets were weaker before this announcement. Importantly, Fitch "has concluded that a 'comprehensive solution' to the eurozone crisis is technically and politically beyond reach." Separately, Fitch affirmed France's AAA rating but revised that country's outlook to negative, saying "the commitments made by leaders at the EU Summit on 9-10 December and by the ECB were not sufficient to put in place a fully credible financial firewall" and "France is in Fitch's judgement the most exposed to a further intensification of the crisis."

column2: As Sales Lag, Stores Shuffle the Calendar
column5: When is the final Saturday before Christmas? Don\xe2\x80\x99t bother consulting a calendar if you\xe2\x80\x99re shopping at Macy\xe2\x80\x99s, Sears or J. C. Penney.

column2: Outrageous Predictions: A Third-Party President?
column5: An extended bank holiday in the European Union to halt a steep market fall, a third party candidate winning the race for the White House, and 50 European banks being nationalized are just a few of Saxo Bank's "outrageous predictions" for 2012.

column2: France Downgrade Would Hit All of Europe: Analysts
column5: French leaders came out fighting this week against rumors that their country's coveted AAA credit rating was under threat, but the reverberations of a French downgrade would be felt around Europe, analysts told CNBC.

column2: Lightning Round: Teva Pharmaceuticals, Pitney Bowes, Caterpillar and More
column5: Teva Pharmaceutical : It feels like Teva has finally bottomed, "Mad Money" host Jim Cramer said. He likes Eli Lill , Sanofi  and Merck , which have been "on fire." He thinks Teva is catching up and will go higher.Pitney Bowes : Cramer is concerned about Pitney Bowes because its revenue has no growth, and without growth it is like owning a bond.E*Trade Financial : Cramer is not recommending any financials other than U.S. Bancorp .Church & Dwight : Talk about a stock that is right, right, right, Cramer said. This consumer products company has its costs under control and is doing incredibly well.Caterpillar : Take an 18 month perspective if you are going to own CAT, Cramer said.Nordic American Tankers : This is the only stock in the tanker business that Cramer's recommending.Call Cramer: 1-800-743-CNBCWhen this story was published, Cramer's charitable trust owned U.S. Bancorp and Sanofi.Questions for Cramer? Questions, comments, suggestions for the Mad Money website? madcap@cnbc.com

column2: India Eyes Drastic Measures as Economic Woes Grow
column5: Growth in Asia\xe2\x80\x99s third largest economy looks buoyant from the shores of blighted markets in the west, but India\xe2\x80\x99s ruling-Congress party is firing warning flares from the deck of a listing ship.

column2: Your First Move for Friday December 16th
column5: Here\xe2\x80\x99s our Fast Money Final Trade. Our gang gives you tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s best trades, right now.Stephen Weiss says he was going to go with managed care, singling out Aetna. \xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99s a compelling industry in a tough environment.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: Finalists for the North American Car and Truck of the Year Announced
column3: Behind the Wheel with Phil Lebeau
column5: The North American Car and Truck of the Yearare considered to be among the most important independent awards given in the auto industry. A panel of 50 auto journalists from across North America picked the finalists from a group of 17 2012 cars and seven 2012 trucks.

column2: Perfect Storm Brewing in Europe: Heineken CEO
column5: Chairman and CEO of Europe's largest brewer, Heineken, Jean-Fran\xc3\xa7ois van Boxmeer, tells CNBC's Christine Tan that a "perfect storm" is brewing in Europe where it is struggling with declining sales as a result of weak consumer sentiment.

column2: The Hottest Question in Europe: Did The ECB Just Pull Off A Back-Door Bailout That Will End the Crisis?
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: Yields on short-term peripheral sovereign bonds\r      are plunging, despite the fact that EU leaders appeared to\r      make little progress at their highly-anticipated summit last\r      week.Pundits continue to expound on the flaws of the eurozone\r      but markets are telling a different tale.That's because the European Central Bank may have already\r      introduced roundabout measures that will solve some of\r      Europe's big problems\xe2\x80\x94it's making investing in\r      peripheral sovereign debt a huge profit opportunity for\r      banks. \r

column2: RIMM Risk In Getting \xe2\x80\x98Too Negative,\xe2\x80\x99 Analyst Says
column5: As Research In Motion falls out of favor with many investors with shares hitting an 8-year low, one \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d analyst maintained a hold rating on the stock. The smartphone maker announced a delay in its new BlackBerry 10 operating system, drawing at least one assessment that the situation was a \xe2\x80\x9cdeath knell\xe2\x80\x9d for the company.

column2: Yuan Outlook is no Yawn: Strategist
column5: The yuan has had a big move against the dollar, and this strategist says there is more to come.\xc2\xa0It's not every day the yuan  rises to a record high against the dollar, but itposted its biggest gain in two months today - possibly thanks to central bank intervention. Greg Salvaggio, senior vice president of capital markets at Tempest Consulting, thinks the move is only logical."We think what the Chinese are doing is really what they've always done - a gradual, managed appreciation of their currency," he says. "What they did is come in overnight and really demonstrate to people 'Hey, we're committed to this appreciation.'" Salvaggio told CNBC's Scott Wapner he thinks the yuan could rise five to seven percent against the dollar in 2012.

column2: Risk Control Strategies: Protecting the 1 Percent
column5: The worse the U.S. economy fares and the bigger the income inequality gap grows, the better business seems to get for Paul Viollis and Douglas Kane. Their New York City-based company, Risk Control Strategies, has doubled its revenues this year by providing security services to the affluent.

column2: Euro Banks Surf the Yield Curve!
column5: Surfing the yield curve: Someone is buying an awful lot of European debt recently, particularly at the short end. Huh? Isn't European debt toxic?

column2: Could Dan Mudd Resign as Fortress CEO?
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: Inside Fortress Investor Group, many people are speculating that Daniel H. Mudd, the chief executive, may step aside soon.Mudd was sued Friday by the Securities and Exchange Commission for securities fraud relating to disclosures of high-risk mortgage exposure at Fannie Mae  during the period when he was that company\xe2\x80\x99s chief executive. Two other executives at Fannie Mae and three at Freddie Mac were also sued Friday.

column2: Cramer: Honeywell Can Weather \xe2\x80\x98European Storm\xe2\x80\x99
column5: Honeywell is one of the best run businesses on the planet, \xe2\x80\x9cMad Money\xe2\x80\x9d host Jim Cramer said Thursday. \xe2\x80\x9cI believe Honeywell  can weather a harsh European storm because it benefits from multiple big picture secular trends ... from the booming aerospace cycle to the need to contain energy costs \xe2\x80\xa6 as well as safety and security,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. Thursday, HON issued in-line sales and earnings guidance for 2012 despite predicting a more challenging macroeconomic backdrop. It also reaffirmed its full-year forecast for 2011. Cramer also likes the fact that the company raised its dividend in October, bringing the yield up to 2.8 percent.He sat down with Chairman and CEO David Cote to find out more about Honeywell\xe2\x80\x99s future. To see the full interview, watch the video.Call Cramer: 1-800-743-CNBCQuestions for Cramer? Questions, comments, suggestions for the Mad Money website? madcap@cnbc.com

column2: Dan Dicker: Crude Oil \xe2\x80\x98Has More to Drop\xe2\x80\x99
column5: Wait for another dip in oil prices to buy, commodities trader Dan Dicker said Thursday on \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 but beware of shorting it. \xe2\x80\x9cThere are better values to be had at lower prices, and I think we\xe2\x80\x99re going to get them,\xe2\x80\x9d the MercBloc president said. \xe2\x80\x9cI think that crude has more to drop.\xe2\x80\x9d Brent crude futures closed down more than 1.5 percent to hit a six-week low. A couple of other plays worth looking at were in oil services, such as Apache and Schlumberger, especially as it approaches $60 per share, he said. Dicker also warned about shorting oil because of uncertainty, such as news that Iran was looking to conduct military exercises in the Strait of Hormuz. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s tough to be short oil because if something like that breaks, you get stuck with a $5 bad bagel with your morning coffee,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThat kind of saber-rattling really doesn\xe2\x80\x99t translate into anything substantial or real, and you have this kind of dropping of oil prices after the headline threat disappears.\xe2\x80\x9d Related StoriesAnalyst Sees Strong Oil Prices, $2,000 Gold AheadUse Oil Rally On Iran Fears to Sell, Say ProsJim Cramer\xe2\x80\x99s Play on High Oil PricesAfter Major Breakdown, Don't Hold Commodities Long-Term\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0______________________________________________________Got something to to say? column2: Your Life on Facebook, in Total Recall
column5: Remember those karaoke videos from three years ago that somehow wound up on Facebook? They were embarrassing for the few hours they spent at the top of your Facebook profile, and then they were buried under a cascade of new updates.

column2: Europe's Periphery Already Shut Out of Credit Markets
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: Heavily indebted nations on Europe's periphery may already have had the doors to European credit markets slammed shut on them, according to a major piece in the Wall Street Journal Friday.

column2: NBC Sports Group Chairman Says NBC Will Profit Off New NFL TV Deal
column5: NBC is paying $950 million a year to extend its rights to Sunday Night Football through the 2022 season. But NBC Sports Group Chairman Mark Lazarus told \xe2\x80\x9cCNBC SportsBiz\xe2\x80\x9d that he\xe2\x80\x99s confident the entire NBC Universal family will make a profit off the investment. (Note: Comcast is the parent company of both NBCUniversal and CNBC)

column2: 'Complacent' Market Unfazed by Quadruple Witching: Trader
column5: Quadruple witching  isn't scaring the stock market Friday, trader Pat Keman of Cardinal Capital Management, told CNBC.The concurrent expiration of contracts for stock index futures, stock index options, stock options, and single stock futures is showing traders are "OK with the short term," Keman said. "Realistically, people are complacent with the rest of the year right now" and are "taking their chips off the table."

column2: Opinion: SBIR Reauthorization Opens Opportunities For Small Business
column5: This guest column was written by Rep. Sam Graves, (R-MO) the Chairman of the House Small Business Committee.Despite the normal gridlock that takes place between the two houses of Congress, this week the House and Senate agreed and passed legislation that will help spur economic growth and create jobs in America\xe2\x80\x94 without any additional taxpayer funding.

column2: S&P 500 Will Reach 1400 in 2012: Strategist
column5: At these levels, equities have nowhere to go but up in 2012, says Alec Young, S&P global equity strategist."We're looking for 1400 on the S&P 500. It would be higher were it not for continued tail risk from Europe, but we're fairly upbeat on next year," says Young. Considering the S&P 500 index on Friday is hovering around $1219, consistent bullish factors will need to kick in next year to prove Young right.\xc2\xa0

column2: Is the Public Tired of Donald Trump? Book Sales Say Yes.
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: The media never seems to tire of Donald Trump. The release of his new book Time To Get Tough: Making America Number One Again on December 5th landed him coverage from just about every media outlet an author could dream of.

column2: United Rentals Snaps Up RSC Holdings for $4.2 Billion
column5: United Rentals announced Friday that it will buy rival RSC Holdings for $4.2 billion in a deal that will create one of North America\xe2\x80\x99s biggest equipment rental companies.

column2: My Love Affair with BlackBerry: Greenberg
column5: I\xe2\x80\x99ve been pretty harsh on Research in Motion lately, going so far as to name the co-CEOs the worst CEOs of the Year.

column2: Pete Najarian\xe2\x80\x99s Heat Seeker Identifies Hot Airline Trade
column5: Pete Najarian always watches options trading to determine what\xe2\x80\x99s on the move. And the latest action suggests an airline could take off.Although he says airlines are not an investment, they\xe2\x80\x99re a trade \xe2\x80\x93 if you\xe2\x80\x99re nimble he thinks you can play Delta  for upside.\xe2\x80\x9cInstitutional investors have been rolling out of the Dec 8 calls and into the Jan 9 calls and March 11 calls,\xe2\x80\x9d he says. \xe2\x80\x9cConsidering oil is coming down and capacity is strong, an upside bet makes sense.\xe2\x80\x9dAnd it\xe2\x80\x99s not the first time that Najarian has spotted this kind of predictive options trading. He says before United Continental  and Jetblue  moved higher he spotted similar call buying.______________________________________________________Got something to to say? column2: Toys 'R US CEO: 'Big Days' Ahead for Holiday Shopping Season
column5: Toys \xe2\x80\x98R Us Chairman and CEO Gerald Storch said he expects the days leading up to Christmas will be \xe2\x80\x9cbig days\xe2\x80\x9d for the retailer.In an interview with CNBC, Storch said consumers have been waiting to shop and now, with only nine days left until Christmas, \xe2\x80\x9cthe starting gun has gone off.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cThere\xe2\x80\x99s been kind of a waiting game with retailers,\xe2\x80\x9d said Storch. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd it looks like the consumer wins.\xe2\x80\x9d The toy retailer has extended its hours for the coming weekend, and starting next Tuesday it will keep its stores open for 112-straight hoursleading into the Christmas holiday.

column2: 2011 Top S&P Stocks: No. 12 TJX
column5: The TJX Companies grew its share price more than 39 percent year to date, making it the No. 12 top-performing S&P stock of 2011. The retail company, which operates T.J. Maxx and Marshalls stores, traded in the $62 range, near its 52-week high of $63.89.

column2: Mortgage-Backed Securities Are Good Bet Now: Gross
column5: The Federal Reserve will keep interest rates low for "three, four, or five years," which is why Pimco is jumping into mortgage-backed securitiesin a big way, the bond giant's founder and co-chief investment officer, Bill Gross, told CNBC Europe Friday.

column2: Free Shipping Day: Boom or Gloom for Merchants?
column5: Happy Free Shipping Day.Or is it? For many online shoppers, a free shipping offer is the holy grail of deals. Forget 20 percent off an item or a coupon for a future discount: free shipping is what makes people click the \xe2\x80\x9cbuy\xe2\x80\x9d button. And today, the fourth annual Free Shipping Day, could mean banner sales for the more than 2,200 merchants that have signed on. Internet marketer Luke Knowles hatched the idea for Free Shipping Day after reading several years ago that 90 percent of consumers buy more when offered free delivery. On Free Shipping Day in 2010, Internet non-travel retail spending hit $942 million, the third-highest one-day total ever. There\xe2\x80\x99s no doubt that free shipping is a significant force in online retail sales. In a recent comScore poll, 42 percent of respondents said it was \xe2\x80\x9csomewhat important\xe2\x80\x9d to \xe2\x80\x9cactively seek out shipping deals,\xe2\x80\x9d while more than one-third (36 percent) said it was \xe2\x80\x9cvery important\xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9cwould not make a purchase without it.\xe2\x80\x9d And more shoppers are taking advantage every year: For the week ended December 4, comScore estimated 63.2 percent of all online retail transactions included free shipping, a full 11 points above the comparable holiday week in 2010. (Even during the rest of the year, levels top 40 percent.) This \xe2\x80\x9cnegative\xe2\x80\x9d cost for the consumer can come at a notable price for the small business owner, who often tentatively skates on ultra-thin margins throughout the year in the hopes of tipping annual profit into the black come December. So what are the costs behind the costs \xe2\x80\x94 is there a dark side to free shipping?

column2: Sunday Ticket In Your Car? DirecTVAuto Has Arrived
column5: Justin Firestone had just bought an SUV when he heard about a cool product. Four hours later, Firestone had live in-motion television with more than 300 channels in his car. It was love at first sight."I couldn't believe how good it was," said Firestone, who used to head up athlete marketing for Marquis Jet. "I was waiting in the parking lot in the car watching TV, while my wife was in the mall shopping."

column2: Holiday Season to Be a Bumpy Ride for Airlines
column5: More Americans will travel during the upcoming holiday season but will avoid the tarmac as the year winds down and the holiday decorations light up.

column2: Spending Traps Last-Minute Shoppers Should Avoid
column5: It\xe2\x80\x99s crunch time. With Christmas and Hanukkah only days away, retailers are trying to entice last-minute shoppers to not only finish their holiday shopping but to buy even more than they might have planned. With the holidays looming, it\xe2\x80\x99s easy to fall prey to these tactics as you frantically gather gifts for those on your list.

column2: At $381 Apple is Undervalued, Here\xe2\x80\x99s Why
column5: If you\xe2\x80\x99re a trader, you constantly hear arguments for and against Apple . According to Sanford Bernstein analyst Toni Sacconaghi Apple bears just don\xe2\x80\x99t get it.He argues that bears only see Apple as a growth stock. And Sacconaghi's proprietary research may reveal why - "We looked at 735 mutual funds; and our study showed Apple is over-owned by growth funds. It\xe2\x80\x99s the most widely held growth stock.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: FTSE, CAC, DAX to Open Higher, US Economic Data Improves
column5: European stocks were called slightly higher on Friday tracking Asia overnight where shares and the euro climbed as investors were calmed by better-than-expected economic data from the US.

column2: Paying a \xe2\x80\x98Sports Tax,\xe2\x80\x99 Even if You Don\xe2\x80\x99t Watch
column5: Are you ready for some football? You are paying for it regardless.

column2: Can Retail Bright Spot Make Up for Europe Gloom?
column5: With one final shopping week to go, investors will be keeping their eye on the consumer to see how holiday sales shake out and what it might mean for the economy.

column2: Market to Stay Flat in 2012: Raymond James CEO
column5: As long as financial problems in Europe and the U.S. continue, the market will remain flat and investors will remain nervous in 2012, the head of Raymond James Financial told CNBC.

column2: Do Emerging Markets Offer Shelter From EU Storm?
column5: Emerging markets offered a good deal of opportunity, even as Europe faces ongoing economic troubles, one \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d pro said Friday. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve got to remember that the emerging markets really have what the U.S. and Europe wish they had: Lots of political will and lots of money,\xe2\x80\x9d David Riedel, president of Riedel Research Group, said Friday. \xe2\x80\x9cThey can really throw a lot of policies at this to turn the taps on to be a lot more expansionary for 2012.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: On Vacation - With Some Good Books
column5: Armed with some new books and one old favorite - I'm taking some time off for the holidays. But I don't want you to think I have forgotten you or your reading needs. If you're still looking for some gift suggestions for your friends, colleagues, loved ones - or you're looking for a good book to bring along on your holiday - have I got some great books for you.Here are some suggestions I've put together for a series called, "For the Book Lover: Best Books for the Holidays 2011" and in "Best Coffee Table Books for 2011"  you'll find suggestions for that persnickety teen, cat lover, nature lover and thrill seeker.2011 has been a terrific year and I'm truly thankful for all of you and for all those wonderful book suggestions you have shared with me.Here's to a terrific New Year - let's hope it's full of more great books.Email me at bullishonbooks@cnbc.com \xe2\x80\x94 And follow me on Twitter

column2: Bank Layoffs Far From Over: 150,000 Likely in 2012: Bove
column5: Banks are likely to see another 150,000 layoffs in 2012 \xe2\x80\x94 on top of the 230,000 estimated for this year \xe2\x80\x94 as government regulations and a weak economy continue to shrink the US financial system, banking analyst Dick Bove said.

column2: Olympic Organizers Missing 'Big Idea' to Inspire Youth?
column5: Using the allure of the Olympics to get more children to play sports is a top target of the London 2012 Olympic Games organizers, but figures from a UK government agency show the number of 16- to 19-year olds playing sports at least three times a week has fallen sharply.

column2: Allen Stanford: I Have 6 Doctors To Prove I'm Incompetent
column5: The attorney for accused Ponzi mastermind R. Allen Stanford plans to call six doctors as well as Stanford's 81-year-old mother and his first defense attorney to testify at a hearing next week on whether he is competent to stand trial.Stanford, 61, is accused of 14 criminal counts in an alleged $7 billion Ponzi scheme. He has denied wrongdoing. His attorneys have argued Stanford suffers from amnesia as a result of a 2009 prison assault and his subsequent addiction to prescription drugs. Prosecutors allege Stanford is faking memory loss to avoid his trial scheduled for next month. In court papers filed Friday, Stanford's court-appointed attorney, Ali Fazel, says he wants to call two neurologists, a neuropsychologist, a forensic psychiatrist, a medical doctor and a staff psychiatrist at the prison medical center in Butner, N.C., where Stanford recently completed nine months of treatment. Four of the doctors are experts employed by the defense. The others are government witnesses that Stanford's team wants to cross-examine.The medical center certified Stanford competent to stand trial, but it will be up to U.S. District Judge David Hittner to decide whether that is the case. The trial is scheduled to begin Jan, 23. Also on the defense witness list for the competency hearing is Stanford's 81-year-old mother Sammie, and Houston attorney Dick DeGuerin, who withdrew as Stanford's defense attorney in 2009 when it became unclear if Stanford would be able to pay him. Today's court filing offers no new clues as to what the witnesses might say, but Stanford's current legal team previously argued he is incapable of assisting in his own defense. Prosecutors plan to call two doctors to testify that Stanford is competent, and they say in a court filing today that there is no need for the amount of testimony the defense is proposing. Next week's competency hearing is crucial for the 28,000 investors in Stanford's alleged scam, because without a criminal trial and a verdict, most of their assets remain in limbo.

column2: A Very Special Holiday GPS to Track Those \xe2\x80\x98Manger and Menorah Marauders\xe2\x80\x99

It\xe2\x80\x99s not \xe2\x80\x9cAway in a Manger,\xe2\x80\x9d it\xe2\x80\x99s away with one.Well, humbug this, Scrooge. Help is on the way. "Jesus Saves, But Who's Saving Jesus?" blares BrickHouse Security, which is donating free GPS services to nonprofits like churches and community groups to protect their holiday displays. "If Baby Jesus or Santa is threatened, attacked or otherwise set upon by thrill-seekers or thieves, a small box imbedded inside the figurine automatically sends a text or email to the owner's mobile phone or computer," writes BrickHouse's Marc Horowitz.

column2: Your Currency Trade for Oil's Move
column5: Global economics may be pushing oil lower, but this strategist says political forces will limit its fall, and she has a trade on that view.\xc2\xa0Sure, Europe's a mess. And sure, global demand for oil has been getting softer. But Rebecca Patterson, chief markets strategist for J.P. Morgan Asset Management, Institutional, says there's a flip side. "What drives oil supply? A lot of it is going to be geopolitics," she says. At the latest OPEC meeting, "what they told us is they're comfortable with current prices."Patterson argues that oil producers have an interest in keeping oil prices at a certain level, since they need to fund their budgets and maintain social stability. If oil drops much lower, she told CNBC's Melissa Lee, "I think they'll intervene to support it. I don't think oil goes a lot lower."To trade that view using currencies, Patterson recommends selling the dollar against the Canadian dollar  since Canada's economy is so closely tied to oil. Specifically, if the greenback moves to 1.0450, she wants to sell it against the Canadian dollar with a stop at 1.0525 and a target of 1.0150. Todd Gordon, co-head of research and trading at Aspen Trading Group, likes the trade from a technical standpoint. "I think oil is a pullback buy, I think the dollar downtrend continues," he says.

column2: Cramer: Sell These \xe2\x80\x98Over-Hyped\xe2\x80\x99 Names
column5: The greater the hype, the greater you need to remain skeptical about the underlying company, Cramer said Friday. And he thinks that\xe2\x80\x99s certainly true when it comes to ZAGG and Skullcandy.ZAGG  makes scratch protectors for devices like smartphones and Skullcandy , which went public over the summer, makes headphones that are used for portable media players and smartphones. Both are pegged as smartphone plays, but they don\xe2\x80\x99t make any smartphones. \xe2\x80\x9cZAGG and Skullcandy sell ancillary products that are ridiculously easily to duplicate \xe2\x80\xa6 so there's nothing stopping potential competitors from coming in and tearing either of them to shreds,\xe2\x80\x9d Cramer said.Both companies also have serious customer concentration issues. ZAGG got 41 percent of its sales from Best Buy last year and doesn\xe2\x80\x99t have a long-term contract with any retailer. Skullcandy gets 10 percent of its sales from Best Buy and 10 percent from Target. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, Cramer sees evidence that business is faltering. In Skullcandy\xe2\x80\x99s first quarter as a public company, it gave guidance that was lower than published estimates. In the latest quarter, its margin declined by 450 basis thanks to higher product costs. Meanwhile, ZAGG has seen its inventories rise rapidly in a business that does have a need for a lot of inventory.\xe2\x80\x9cZAGG and Skullcandy are way, way too dangerous for you to own,\xe2\x80\x9d Cramer said, \xe2\x80\x9cand they both should be sold into any strength.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: Cramer Picks His Fave Pipeline Play
column5: Cramer turned his attention to two high-yielding master limited partnerships on Monday, including Kinder Morgan Energy Partners  and Plains All American Pipeline .Both names are worth considering, but between the two, Cramer prefers KMP. It has more diversification, which bodes well for the company in the long-term. But it also has plans to purchase El Paso Energy. The deal is expected to close in the next quarter of next year and while Cramer thinks it\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x9cbrilliant,\xe2\x80\x9d he noted there are five parties involved in the transaction and it can be a little confusing to follow. Therefore, he worries the deal might be a distraction and could increase the odds this stock temporarily stumbles.So while KMP is his favorite pipeline play, Cramer might choose PAA in the short-term. PAA has several near-term catalysts, including a series of acquisitions totally $2.3 billion and plans to grow its distribution by 8 to 9 percent next year.But while PAA could produce slightly better gains in the next six to 12 months, Cramer thinks KMP will be the long-term winner overall.

column2: Spending, Lending Continue to Challenge Franchisees
column5: Four years of depressed consumer spending have taken a toll on franchisees, who are less optimistic about sales heading into 2012 than they were one year ago. That\xe2\x80\x99s according to a survey released today from the International Franchise Association Education Foundation.In addition to concern about spending, lack of access to credit, combined with \xe2\x80\x9cnegative rhetoric coming out of Washington,\xe2\x80\x9d are two factors stymieing growth, says respondents to the survey, which was conducted by HIS Global Insight for the IFA.While 66.6 percent of franchisees said they expect to see moderate to significant increase in sales in 2012, that number is down from 76.4 percent in 2010. Concerns about tax reform and health care are other factors contributing to franchisees\xe2\x80\x99 pessimistic outlook.Even with the muted outlook, IFA president & CEO Steve Caldeira said that franchises\xe2\x80\x99 expected growth is \xe2\x80\x9coutpacing projected growth in the overall economy, \xe2\x80\x9c and projects the number of franchise jobs to grow 2.1 percent in 2012.

column2: How to Trade the Swedish Central Bank Meeting
column5: Sweden's Riksbank will meet and reach an interest rate decision Tuesday. Here's how to get ready.Yes, there are happenings in Europe outside the euro zone. Here's one: Sweden's central bank is meeting on Tuesday, and an interest rate decision will ensue. Investors seem to be divided on whether there will be a 25 basis-point rate cut, but some are starting to think there could be even more. Not so fast, says Marc Chandler, chief currency strategist at Brown Brothers Harriman. "We think there is scope for disappointment and suspect standing pat is likely than a 50 bp cut," he wrote in a note to clients. Chandler points out that while inflation is low and sentiment surveys are deteriorating, third quarter growth ran at a very respectable 4.6% and Sweden's trade surplus is holding up.Others disagree, however. At Citigroup the betting is on a 50 basis point cut, "although there is a chance it will do just 25bp." At Barclays Capital, analysts think a 25 basis point move is most likely - and "as poor liquidity is also likely to weigh on the SEK next week, we think the risk reward favors being long USD/SEK," they wrote in a research note.\xc2\xa0 And then there is the euro zone. Chandler says the krona's direction will depend as much on events there as on anything else. After all, he says, Norway cut interest rates 50 basis points, surprising just about everyone, and the krone  has risen against both the dollar and the euro since then. Stay tuned. -----------------------------MULTI CURRENCIES v The DollarCURRENCY FUTURESTune In: CNBC's "Money in Motion Currency Trading" airs on Fridays at 5:30pm and repeats on Saturdays at 7pm. column2: Draghi's 'Silence' Drags on Markets

column2: Making a List, and Taking It to the Pawnshop
column5: Children in San Mateo, Calif., whispered their wish lists to Santa Claus this weekend at Best Collateral, a pawnshop in a strip mall about 20 miles south of San Francisco.And if their parents didn\xe2\x80\x99t mind discounted gifts \xe2\x80\x94 well, to be realistic, used or hocked ones \xe2\x80\x94 they did their shopping there, too. Christmas this year has come to the neighborhood pawnshop \xe2\x80\x94 and business is booming like never before. Sue Gallagher, 54, is one shopper who now works through her Christmas list at a pawnshop before heading to Wal-Mart  or Target . She recently bought a television for her daughter at Tom\xe2\x80\x99s Pawn Shop in Lake Jackson, Tex., a \xe2\x80\x9cdecent-sized flat-screen TV for less than $100.\xe2\x80\x9d She described the experience as festive, with \xe2\x80\x9cgarlands and tinsel and some music playing in the background.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cI didn\xe2\x80\x99t feel like I was shopping in a pawnshop,\xe2\x80\x9d said Ms. Gallagher, who works for a nursing service. Tom\xe2\x80\x99s is not the only pawnshop that is thriving. At the Pawn America chain of stores in the Midwest, the founder Brad Rixmann said his business was up 50 percent this holiday season over last year. In San Diego, Yigal Adato, a co-owner of CashCo Pawn, said customers were showing up with Christmas lists, desperate to save money. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve had a couple of customers who say, \xe2\x80\x98You know, if it wasn\xe2\x80\x99t for you guys\xe2\x80\x99 prices, my kids wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be getting anything this year,\xe2\x80\x99 \xe2\x80\x9c Mr. Adato said. While some customers have always bought Christmas gifts at pawnshops, only recently has the idea gained widespread acceptance, said Emmett Murphy, a spokesman for the National Pawnbrokers Association. So far, this holiday season has been the best one yet, he said. Many pawnshops, in turn, are embracing holiday shoppers like never before, offering promotions long deployed by more traditional stores, like \xe2\x80\x9c25 Days of Deals,\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cBlack Friday\xe2\x80\x9d specials\xe2\x80\x94 even visits from Santa. It underlines how the recession has hit those at the bottom of the economic spectrum, for whom even Wal-Mart can be too expensive. \xe2\x80\x9cWe want people to think of us as an alternative to Target, Best Buy,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Rixmann said. \xe2\x80\x9cYou can buy stocking stuffers for next to nothing.\xe2\x80\x9d The gloomy economy is the most immediate explanation, but industry experts also point to the success of television shows like \xe2\x80\x9cPawn Stars,\xe2\x80\x9d which have attracted a more mainstream audience to the stores.

column2: Sink Your Teeth Into Yum! Brands
column5: Now is the time of year to eat, drink and be merry. So how can you profit off the \xe2\x80\x9ceating\xe2\x80\x9d part of that holiday equation? \xe2\x80\x9cMad Money\xe2\x80\x9d host Jim Cramer would sink his teeth into Yum! Brands, which operates KFC, Taco Bell and Pizza Hut. Yum  is \xe2\x80\x9cone of the best restaurant stocks around, and a terrific buy, especially on a pullback that the Europeans seem increasingly prone to give us between now and the end of the year,\xe2\x80\x9d Cramer said Monday. It is also has one of the strongest international growth stories he's ever seen in the restaurant space. China should account for 45 percent of Yum\xe2\x80\x99s operating profit for this year. The Louisville, Ky.-based company has 4,200 locations in China and Cramer believes it could easily double that footprint. Plus, Chinese same-store sales rose 19 percent in the most recent quarter. The company is also rapidly expanding outside around the rest of the globe. Yum\xe2\x80\x99s non-China overseas division should account for 30 percent of its 2011 operating profit. Yum is forecasting a 34 percent increase in units next year and a 23 percent increase in same-store sales.The U.S. has become the least important part of Yum\xe2\x80\x99s business, but the company still expects its domestic profits to grow 5 percent next year. It has decided to refranchise many of its domestic stores, which Cramer thinks makes sense since it guarantees a stable revenue stream from royalty payments. The company is also working hard to turn the domestic business around by laying off workers at Taco Bell, restructuring KFC and adding new menu items at Pizza Hut. Plus, there has been some speculation that it may sell the Taco Bell division or the entire U.S. segment. While Cramer wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t bank on that happening, he thinks it could be very positive if it does.Selling at 17.8 times next year\xe2\x80\x99s earnings, with a 12.7 percent growth rate, Cramer doesn\xe2\x80\x99t think this stock is too expensive. However, he\xe2\x80\x99d like it more on a pullback since the stock is less than two points off its 52-week high. \xe2\x80\x9cBe patient and you\xe2\x80\x99ll get a chance to buy this fantastic international eating story at a discount the next time we get a European-induced market wide sell-off,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. column2: Buy the Dip in Cloud Computing Stocks: Analysts
column5: With Europe on a fiscal austerity program, virtualization\r    companies have come under pressure. This might be a good buying\r    opportunity, several analysts say.There has been no trend among European companies that they\r    are cutting back in information technology spending, and\r    overseas revenue has been strong, said Rajesh Ghai of Think\r    Equity. Virtualization has an extremely compelling economic\r    argument, and Europe has held steady.

column2: Sprint Loses from AT&T Failed Acquisition of T-Mobile, Huh?
column5: In the after market shares of Sprint climbed as investors bet AT&T\xe2\x80\x99s failed bid to acquire T-Mobile benefited the number 3 wireless carrier.But Sanford Bernstein analyst Craig Moffett tells us investors got it wrong."Ironically, Sprint would have benefited the most from the deal happening. And now they\xe2\x80\x99re the biggest loser.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: FTSE, CAC 40, DAX to Open Lower; North Korean Leader Dies
column5: European stocks were called to open lower on Monday tracking overnight trade in Asia where stocks were hit by fears of possible ratings downgrades in Europe and the death of North Korean leader Kim Jong il.

column2: Market\xe2\x80\x99s Inability to Rally, Bad Omen for January: Grasso
column5: On Monday traders on the floor were starting to doubt whether the highly touted chase for performance into end of year \xe2\x80\x93 was in fact going to happen at all.Both the Dow and S&P slipped lower, calling into question predictions of a melt up over the next two weeks.Top trader Steve Grasso tells us chatter on the floor hasn't been optimistic lately, not by any stretch. \xe2\x80\x9cIf we can\xe2\x80\x99t rally going into Christmas where will the market end up in the first quarter of 2012?\xe2\x80\x9d That's what Grasso is hearing. And it's a problem for bulls because it reduces appetite for risk. \xe2\x80\x9cRight now nobody on the floor wants to take a flier,\xe2\x80\x9d he adds.The unwillingness to buy may be due to recent comments made by ECB president Mario Draghi - he suggested the year ahead would be perilous for Europe. Despite hopes that overseas headlines and the S&P would de-couple, \xe2\x80\x9cThe market continues to be focused on the Euro-Zone,\xe2\x80\x9d Grasso says. Draghi also discussed the possibility of a euro breakup in an interview with The Financial Times, although he said the interview\xe2\x80\x99s\xc2\xa0 purpose was to dispel rumors. The Street, however didn\xe2\x80\x99t take it that way. The Street took it to mean \xe2\x80\x9cThe world is a scary place,\xe2\x80\x9d Grasso explains.

column2: Adami Offers Cablevision Play On Citi\xe2\x80\x99s \xe2\x80\x98Buy\xe2\x80\x99
column5: Cablevision shares could offer trading opportunities after a dip on the news of a high-profile departure, \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d pro Guy Adami said Monday. \xe2\x80\x9cEverything is worth a look at in terms of a trade,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cThis is a name that if you believe in the tape you can definitely buy this stock for a trade, looking probably for $14.50, $15 and maybe your stop-loss somewhere around the levels we saw on Friday.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: Stop Hoping for EU Debt Solution: Cramer
column5: U.S. stocks closed lower Monday with the worst losses having occurred in the banking sector, as investors worried the Basel III capital requirements would provide another blow to the industry.To make matters worse, European Central Bank head Mario Draghi gave a speech that did little to support how the region\xe2\x80\x99s sovereign debt crisis could be solved. But Cramer thinks investors should stop waiting for the day when someone will come along and rescue all entities caught in Europe\xe2\x80\x99s debt woes. Hope, Cramer said, should never be a part of the investing equation. Instead, investors should look for stocks with upside, such as Consolidated Edison , Dominion Resources or Duke Energy . All of these stocks, by the way, offer juicy dividend yields. Read on for Cramer's Top Dividend Stocks 2011.

column2: After Death of North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s Leader, Sell This: Kelly
column5: A sudden turn of events usually presents opportunities for traders, and on Monday North Korea\xe2\x80\x99s Kim Jong-il died very suddenly.As you may know the 69 year old autocrat, who was also called \xe2\x80\x98Dear Leader\xe2\x80\x99 suffered a heart attack while on a train trip reviewing his nation\xe2\x80\x99s factories farms and military bases.Kim Jong un, Kim Jong il's youngest son, was named by North Korea's official news agency KCNA as the "great successor" to his father, which lauded him as "the outstanding leader of our party, army and people".

column2: Won Slides, Euro Dips, Dollar Gets a Lift
column5: Kim Jong Il KOs the won, and the euro eases as investors get edgy - it's time for your FX Fix. The death of North Korea's Kim Jong Il created uncertainty that gave the dollar a lift, while the euro inched lower on worries about the crisis. [CNBC]South Korea's won tumbled on news of Kim Jong Il's death. [WSJ] The European Central Bank's Mario Draghi warned of the costs of a euro zone breakup. [FT]A near absence of U.S. economic data as the end of the year approaches could hurt market sentiment. [forexyard.com]A Dutch theme park ran a weekend promotion accepting guilders instead of euros.
