column2: Donald Trump Takes Over Cafe Hurt by OWS
column5: A local New York restaurant that saw business drop off as Occupy Wall Street protests erupted nearby has finally shut its doors \xe2\x80\x94 and will be taken over by the ultimate 1 percenter, Donald Trump.The real-estate magnate, who owns the building at 40 Wall Street, where Milk Street Cafe was located, has retained the restaurant hall for "pennies on the dollar," according to a source close to the deal, and will turn the all-kosher cafe into a Trump Street Bar & Grille.

column2: Obama Testing 2-Tier Strategy for Re-election
column5: WASHINGTON \xe2\x80\x94 Just three hours afterPresident Obama announced that he was defying Congressional Republicans to fill a high-level regulatory position while lawmakers were out of town, Mitt Romney sent out the obligatory news release ripping the president. \xe2\x80\x9cChicago-style politics at its worst,\xe2\x80\x9d Mr. Romney fumed, accusing the president of \xe2\x80\x9ccircumventing Congress.\xe2\x80\x9dThe statement was just what the White House wanted. It put the Republican presidential front-runner squarely on the side of the Republicans in Congress, a group with toxic poll numbers that the president\xe2\x80\x99s campaign hopes will hurt his rivals for the White House. \xe2\x80\x9cOur presidential election campaign is not a campaign against Congress,\xe2\x80\x9d a senior administration official said on Thursday. \xe2\x80\x9cWe know we\xe2\x80\x99ll run against a person.\xe2\x80\x9d But insofar as Mr. Obama has decided to target Republicans in Congress \xe2\x80\x94 a body with historically low approval ratings after a year of jousting with the president \xe2\x80\x94 he will also be seeking to twin his opponent, to any extent he can, with the 112th Congress. Upon the president\xe2\x80\x99s return from Hawaii, the Obama campaign this week unleashed a carefully scripted and deliberately aggressive strategy that showed a White House in combative re-election mode as the president and his advisers sought to ensure that the Republicans did not get all the political limelight. Mr. Obama inserted himself into the media blitz of what was supposed to be an all-Republican show, the Iowa caucuses, when his campaign took out a huge advertisement on the home page of The Des Moines Register on caucus day and he spoke by video conference to Democrats gathered in the state. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Republican candidates are leaving Iowa. But their terrible plans are here to stay,\xe2\x80\x9d was the declaration that greeted readers who went to the newspaper\xe2\x80\x99s Web site to get caucus updates. On Wednesday, after waiting until the dust in Iowa had settled, clearing out space in newspapers and on television, Mr. Obama delivered another jab, announcing four recess appointments, including that of Richard Cordray as head of a new consumer protection agency, despite Republican opposition. On Thursday, the president went to the Pentagon and outlined a new military strategy that embraces hundreds of billions of dollars in cuts to what is a Republican sacred cow, and made it clear that American ground forces would no longer be large enough to conduct prolonged, large-scale counterinsurgency campaigns like those in Iraq and Afghanistan. On Friday, he will take a victory lap with Mr. Cordray in a visit with the staff of the new Consumer Finance Protection Bureau. White House and administration officials insist that all of Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s actions this week \xe2\x80\x94 with the exception of the advertisement \xe2\x80\x94 are policy decisions made for the good of the country. But from Marine One \xe2\x80\x94 the helicopter where Mr. Obama and Mr. Cordray revved up on Wednesday for the forthcoming fight \xe2\x80\x94 to the West Wing corridors to his campaign offices in Chicago, the president\xe2\x80\x99s battle for re-election is quickly escalating as he sets out to use the advantages of his office to full effect. The president\xe2\x80\x99s move last fall to take his jobs plan on the road to try to sell it to the American public, an effort that culminated in the extension battle that is now widely perceived as a win for Mr. Obama and a debacle for Congressional Republicans, was just the beginning, administration officials and Mr. Obama\xe2\x80\x99s advisers say.

column2: Jobs Outlook in Small Business: Let's Review
column5: It was a week where just when you thought you knew what the story was, it changed. So, let\xe2\x80\x99s review:We\xe2\x80\x99ll start with jobs. Overall, 200,000 new jobs were created in December, and the unemployment rate dropped to 8.5 percent, surprising many who expected that number to rise after the holiday hiring spree. No doubt hiring was up in December, a fact that was attributable, in part, to small business, according to at least one economist. Diane Swonk, chief economist at Mesirow Financial, echoed her theory from last month regarding the ADP payroll report, which noted that in December, 325,000 private-sector jobs were added. \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s good news and that story continues to grow,\xe2\x80\x9d she told CNBC.com\xe2\x80\x99s Patti Domm. \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s one we want to keep momentum on, and that\xe2\x80\x99s small business formation \xe2\x80\xa6 That\xe2\x80\x99s seen a real turn.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: Confidence in London Property Market Falls
column5: Concerns about the crisis in the euro zone and the effect of sweeping regulatory changes on bank lending have pushed confidence in London\xe2\x80\x99s commercial property market to the lowest level in two years.

column2: New Hampshire: Vote Free or Die
column5: The other day, I took a very pleasant one-hour drive north from Boston to New Hampshire to check out the CNBC New Hampshire Primary Headquarters. I pulled off I-93 and took local roads because I wanted to get lost in the New Hampshire countryside. I will admit the media only parachutes in and out of the big city but never takes a quiet drive to get a lay of the land.\xc2\xa0 With some spare time, I wanted to see what the fuss was all about this time around.

column2: UK Retailer Tesco Set for Worst Christmas in Decades
column5: Tesco is forecast to deliver its worst Christmas sales performance in the UK for decades, amid reports of tensions at the top of Britain\xe2\x80\x99s biggest retailer over its unsuccessful price-cutting campaign.

column2: Stanford Says His Constitutional Rights Were Violated
column5: Accused Ponzi mastermind Allen Stanford, who is scheduled to go on trial in two weeks on charges he ran a $7 billion scam, says the case should be dismissed because his constitutional rights were violated.

column2: Lightning Round: BreitBurn Energy, Darden Restaurants, Vail Resorts and More
column5: BreitBurn Energy : Cramer prefers Energy Transfer Partners , a stock his charitable trust has been buying shares of lately.

column2: 4 Dow Stocks to Outperform In 2012
column5: As all three averages logged strong gains to close the first week of the new year, Cramer on Friday revealed the four stocks he expects to outperform the Dow Jones industrial average  in 2012.General ElectricMany of General Electric\xe2\x80\x99s businesses seem likely to do well in the year ahead, Cramer said. The Fairfield, Conn.-based company is engaged in\xc2\xa0 energy infrastructure, integrated electrical equipment, aerospace and much more.Meanwhile, the company recently raised its dividend by 13.3 percent. The stock currently sports a 3.7 percent dividend yield.Finally, Cramer thinks the stock is \xe2\x80\x9cdirt cheap.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s selling for 11.7 times forward earnings, which is cheap compared to its 13.4 percent long-term growth rate. Plus, it\xe2\x80\x99s trading at a 20 percent discount to its historical multiple.Kraft FoodsBased in Northfield, Ill., Kraft is the largest packaged food company in the United States. Its products are found in 99 percent of American households, Cramer said. Some investors may think this company sounds boring, but Cramer noted that boring, dividend-paying stocks were the savior of many individual\xe2\x80\x99s portfolios last year. After all, high-yielding stocks pay investors to wait until the stock market calms and the economy improves. So no matter what\xe2\x80\x99s going on in the world, dividend-paying stocks are still turning investors a profit. For its part, Kraft sports a 3.1 percent dividend yield.In addition to Kraft\xe2\x80\x99s dividend, Cramer likes the stock because of the company\xe2\x80\x99s plans to break-up. He thinks management can unlock value by splitting the company into two parts: a fast-growing snacks company called SnackCo. and a domestic grocery business named GroceryCo. The split won\xe2\x80\x99t likely happen until the end of the year, but in the meantime, Cramer thinks Kraft\xe2\x80\x99s stock will rise in anticipation. So he thinks the stock is a great buy at current levels and wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t be surprised if it outperforms the Dow.AT&TThe wireless communications company\xe2\x80\x99s stock had been a laggard in 2011 thanks to the collapse of its plans to acquire rival T-Mobile USA. In March 2011, AT&T announced plans to purchase T-Mobile from Deutsche Telekom  of Germany for $39 billion. Had the deal gone through, AT&T would have become the largest cellphone company in the U.S. AT&T\xe2\x80\x99s proposal was met with opposition from the\xc2\xa0 Department of Justice and the Federal Communications Commission, though. In August 2011, the Justice Department sued to block the merger, saying it would reduce competition and lead to higher prices. Months later, the companies withdrew their application to the Federal Communications Commission after its chairman also opposed the deal. The FCC claimed the merger would result in a massive loss of U.S. jobs and investment, and significantly diminish competition, while the DOJ said it would lead to higher wireless prices for consumers and businesses.After facing such fierce opposition from government regulators, AT&T last month ended its proposed purchase of T-Mobile.But the stock is now pricing in market share losses that haven\xe2\x80\x99t happened, so the \xe2\x80\x9cMad Money\xe2\x80\x9d host thinks it\xe2\x80\x99s just way too cheap at current levels.\xe2\x80\x9cNow the company can go back to focusing on the fundamentals, building its business with small deals, and coining money courtesy of its near-duopoly status in wireless,\xe2\x80\x9d Cramer said.AT&T also pays a juicy dividend yield. Cramer tends to like high-yielding stocks because they pay investors to wait until the stock market calms and the economy improves. The dividends can be reinvested into the stock.BoeingThe airplane maker is posed to have one of its best years in ages, the "Mad Money" host said, because it is benefitting from the powerful aerospace cycle. Right now, airlines desperately need to buy the latest fuel-efficient planes in order to reduce sky-high fuel costs. And to Cramer, Boeing is the most obvious way to play this cycle.Boeing already had a good year in 2011, Cramer noted, with its stock up 10.8 percent when reinvested dividends are included. He thinks 2012 will be just as profitable because commercial airplane orders rose by 52 percent last year to 805 aircraft and the company had a backlog of 3,771 planes in the pipeline. Looking ahead, the new orders should only continue to grow.Another reason Cramer likes Boeing is because it pays a dividend. Last month, the company raised its dividend by 5 percent. So it now yields at nearly 2.4 percent.On top of it all, the stock is selling for just 14.8 times earnings with a 13.4 long-term growth rate that may be too conservative. To Cramer, this stock is simply a bargain.

column5: Boeing is one of four stocks likely to outperform the Dow Jones industrial average in 2012, Cramer said Friday.The airplane maker  is posed to have one of its best years in ages, the "Mad Money" host said, because it is benefitting from the powerful aerospace cycle. So it now yields at nearly 2.4 percent.On top of it all, the stock is selling for just 14.8 times earnings with a 13.4 long-term growth rate that may be too conservative. column2: Wall Street Is Bracing for Dismal 4th Quarter
column5: For most Wall Street bankers, 2011 was a year they would rather forget. Investors will soon find out just how bad that year was for the country\xe2\x80\x99s biggest financial institutions.

column2: Asian Nations Seek to Reduce Oil Purchases From Iran
column5: Under growing pressure from the United States, some of Asia\xe2\x80\x99s largest economies are reluctantly looking for options to reduce the amount of oil they buy from Iran, a move that would further tighten the economic vise on an increasingly defiant nation that announced plans for a new round of naval drills in the Strait of Hormuz.

column2: Week Ahead: Market Will Be Tested by Earnings, Europe, Iran
column5: Cross currents from Europe, a gaggle of Fed speakers and the start of the corporate earnings season combine to make the coming week a critical test for markets in the new year.

column2: Cramer Backs Alexion Stock
column5: All this week, Cramer compared the strongest performers of both the S&P 500 and Nasdaq and on Friday, he decided that Alexion Pharmaceuticals  is the best of the bunch.Based in Cheshire, Conn., Alexion is a biopharmaceutical company that engages in the discovery and development of biological therapeutic products for treating patients with severe and life-threatening diseases.\xc2\xa0 Cramer likes its stock for many reasons, such as it has a low PEG ratio, a metric that relates growth rate to valuation. Alexion is currently trading at 1.2 times growth.Alexion is also a prime takeover candidate, especially as big pharma companies have been hungry to snap up these kind of orphan drug developers. The company has a lot of potential, too, because its main drug could be approved for multiple new indications.So Cramer recommends investors consider ALXN at current levels.Call Cramer: 1-800-743-CNBCQuestions for Cramer? Questions, comments, suggestions for the Mad Money website? madcap@cnbc.com

column2: Can 'Super Mario' Save the Euro?
column5: The euro is getting pummeled, and the upcoming European Central Bank meeting is unlikely to change its course.The past week was a rough one for the euro,  what with a crisis in Hungary, a raft of government bond sales, the looming threat of sovereign credit-rating cuts, and disappointing economic data. Next week won't be any better, says Amelia Bourdeau, director of foreign exchange at Westpac Institutional Bank."I'm very cautious on the euro," she says, especially with a meeting of the European Central Bank on the horizon as grim economic indicators pile up. Bourdeau told CNBC's Melissa Leeshe doesn't expect the bank's president, Mario Draghi, to announce an interest rate cut despite the gloomy headlines, but she's not sure anything the bank does could help the euro right now. Rebecca Patterson, chief markets strategist for J.P. Morgan Asset Management, Institutional, agrees. "In recent months, when the ECB did cut, the euro fell. But when policy makers are seen as not acting fast enough to stem the crisis, the euro falls anyway," she says. "It's a matter of degree but not direction."The picture in the U.S. is very different, Bourdeau says, noting that comments from Federal Reserve officials next week are likely to highlight the differences between the prospects for the U.S. and European economies - with the dollar reaping some benefit.Bourdeau wants to sell the euro against the dollar,  entering the trade at 1.2760 and looking for a move to 1.2500, with a stop at 1.2830.\xc2\xa0

column2: Iran\xe2\x80\x99s Central Bank Chief Not Resigning: Report
column5: The Governor of the Central Bank of Iran (CBI) has not stepped down despite rumors to the contrary, according to comments carried by the semi-official Fars news agency.

column2: Private Sector Gets Job Skills; Public Gets Bill
column5: KERNERSVILLE, N.C. \xe2\x80\x94 Some of Caterpillar\xe2\x80\x99s newest factory workers are training inside a former carpet warehouse here in the heart of tobacco country. In classrooms, they click through online tutorials and study blueprints emblazoned with the company\xe2\x80\x99s logo. And on a mock factory floor, they learn to use wrenches, hoses and power tools that they will need to build axles for large mining trucks.

column2: Netflix\xe2\x80\x99s Big Pop and Zynga\xe2\x80\x99s Big Drop
column5: It\xe2\x80\x99s a tale of two stocks: Netflix flying 13.8 percent higher Monday while Zynga plummeted 9.2 percent. So what drove the big moves?

column2: S.Korean Shipbuilders Mull $1.3 Billion Bid for French GTT
column5: South Korea\xe2\x80\x99s three biggest shipbuilders \xe2\x80\x93 Hyundai, Daewoo and Samsung \xe2\x80\x93 are discussing a joint bid for French group Gaztransport & Technigaz valued at about \xe2\x82\xac1 billion ($1.3 billion), aiming to head off a Chinese challenge, according to people close to the talks.

column2: Detroit Auto Show: Automakers Won't Party Like it's 1999
column3: Behind the Wheel with Phil Lebeau
column5: Smiles, record sales, surging profits.There hasn't been this type of energy at the Detroit Auto Showin years. To quote , "It's a different world. It's like a throwback to the 90's. This is the kind of atmosphere we used to have at the Detroit Auto Show when things were going well." Hmmmm. I'm not sure that's a good thing or a bad thing. Yes, back then the U.S. auto industry was racking up huge profits pumping out big SUV's powered by cheap gas. Detroit's automakers were defiant whenever someone suggested the Big 3 should be worried about not getting their costs lower. Yeah, we know what happened a few years later.

column2: Tim Tebow\xe2\x80\x99s Autobiography \xe2\x80\x98Through My Eyes\xe2\x80\x99: The Best Selling Sports Book Of 2011
column5: Nathan Whitaker stood in the back at a book signing in Gainesville and watched his co-author, and subject, Tim Tebow sign books for fans.\xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve sat next to Tony Dungy and one in every 20 come through in tears,\xe2\x80\x9d said Whitaker, a former capologist for Jacksonville Jaguars and Tampa Bay Buccaneers who went on to write three best-selling books with Dungy. \xe2\x80\x9cWith Tim, it was like every other person. People would literally come up to touch him while he was signing their book and some kids would be unable to move.\xe2\x80\x9dOver the past year, Tim Tebow has grabbed the attention of the sports world. So much so, that his book \xe2\x80\x9cThrough My Eyes,\xe2\x80\x9d written with Whitaker, was the best-selling sports book of the year. Nielsen Bookscan says that 185,000 books were sold, besting "ESPN: The Uncensored History,which sold 115,000 books in hardcover in 2011. But Lisa Sharkey, Harper Collins\xe2\x80\x99 senior vice president and creative director, who acquired the book says sales are much higher than that number reflects.

column2: Affordable Care Act Study Shows Billions of Dollars In Hidden Costs
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: The "Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act" has been a lightning rod since its inception. Both sides of the aisle have used a different set of numbers to support stances both for and against the law. In effort to break through the polarizing politics of this Act, the Mercatus Center at George Mason University conducted a year long study called "Beware the Rush to Presumption." It analyzes the \xc2\xa0government's own analysis of the program's cost savings and benefits. Dr. Jerry Ellig is a scholar at the Mercatus Center at George Mason University and is the study's co-author.\xc2\xa0

column2: A Tech Show Loses Clout as Industry Shifts
column5: The International Consumer Electronics Show, which will open on Tuesday in Las Vegas, is impossible to ignore. It will smother the city\xe2\x80\x99s gigantic convention center with gadgets and those who make and promote them; more than 140,000 people are expected to attend for a frenzy of old-fashioned social networking with other members of the tech set.

column2: Hopes for Fresh Chinese Reforms Dashed
column5: Signs that China is losing its appetite for key financial reforms are fuelling concerns that the country will remain on a path of unbalanced growth, increasing the chances of a future economic crisis.

column2: Netflix Could \xe2\x80\x98Go Crazy to the Upside,\xe2\x80\x99 Whitney Tilson
column5: Up 33% ytd, Netflix is emerging as the best performer in the S&P. And hedge fund manager and CNBC Contributor Whitney Tilson thinks gains are just starting.Tilson has been bullish on Netflix since the stock traded around $77 late last year.\xc2\xa0 And although the stock has already made a sizeable move, he tells us, \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s a long way from the point at which I\xe2\x80\x99d sell it.\xe2\x80\x9dHe gave us 4 reasons for his bullish outlook:1. Street over reacted to the downside and nobody wanted it on the books at year\xe2\x80\x99s end2. Rumors of buyout are swirling and with less than a $5 billion market cap, Netflix makes an easy acquisition for a number of large players3. Launched services in UK and Ireland, a real international growth story that nobody has paid attention to.4. CEO Reed Hastings says US subscriber growth is growing again It\xe2\x80\x99s worth noting that Tilson looks at Netflix as an investment, not a trade. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m in this with a multi-year horizon,\xe2\x80\x9d he says.

column2: 9 Rich-Kid Stocks Bucking the Terrible Economy
column5: Most of the world's wealthiest people have no conception that the rest of us have been living in a gut-wrenching recession for the past three years.Just look at their profligate spending: $400 for skin-tight, ripped blue jeans; $68 for a rubber mat to perform the ascetic practice of yoga; $9,000 for diamond earrings that look like chandeliers; and $100,000-plus for a car when the average American home sells for $260,000.

column2: Is Amazon Poised to Eat Akamai\xe2\x80\x99s Lunch?
column5: Akamai, facing increased competition from the likes of Amazon, was downgraded to \xe2\x80\x9csell\xe2\x80\x9d from \xe2\x80\x9cneutral\xe2\x80\x9d by one \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d analyst. Citigroup analyst Mark Mahaney noted that he had been bullish on the company in the past. \xe2\x80\x9cOne thing that\xe2\x80\x99s new, though, however, is the competitive landscape has changed,\xe2\x80\x9d he said Monday. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Amazon, particularly, is making a much bigger move against this company.\xe2\x80\x9d Mahaney said that the end market has experienced year-over-year growth upward of 30 percent.

column5: Merger Monday kicks off the JPMorgan Health Care conference with Bristol Meyers acquiring Inhibitex, a small biotech firm that is working on a Hepatitis C treatment.

column2: Vermin Supreme for President?
column5: Anyone can run for President, as long as you were born here, you've lived in the country for 14 years, and you're at least 35 years old.Anyone. Even Vermin Supreme.

column2: Dunkin' Donuts Plans Big Expansion, Incentives for Franchisees
column5: Dunkin' Donuts has kicked off 2012 with big plans for an aggressive expansion \xe2\x80\x94 and that includes a range of new opportunities and incentives for potential franchisees.The quick-service coffee and doughnut chain seeks to double its U.S. locations over the next 20 years, providing exponentially more opportunities for franchisees, job seekers and doughnut consumers alike. Currently, the company has about 9,500 locations, 7,000 of which are in the U.S. and predominantly franchisee-operated.

column2: Alcoa CEO: Positive Signs in the Economy
column5: Alcoa CEO Klaus Kleinfeld is seeing improvements in the U.S. economy and maintains his forecast for aluminum demand doubling until 2020.

column2: Implant Scare at Tough Time for Cosmetic Surgery Industry
column5: The furor over bursting breast implants in Europe comes at a time when the cosmetic surgery industry there is already facing a difficult year.

column2: 3 Stocks Added to Goldman Sachs' Favorite-Picks List
column5: Goldman Sachs analysts shook up its so-called conviction buy list on Monday, adding Dow component Travelers Cos., apparel maker Ralph Lauren and hedge fund Och-Ziff Capital Management as their best investment ideas.To make room for Goldman's three new picks, retailer TJX Cos., insurance company XL Group and asset manager BlackRock were bumped from the list of prime stocks.

column2: Millions of Chinese Won't Have to Hear Warren Buffett Sing
column5: Music lovers in China can relax.\xc2\xa0 The report that Warren Buffett would sing and play guitar for the Chinese New Year turns out not to be accurate.Last week, the official Chinese news agency Xinhua reported Buffett had recorded a song for the online version of China's extremely popular annual Spring Festival TV show.\xc2\xa0 Xinhua quoted production exec Wang Pingjiu as saying, "We all know that Buffett is good at investment, but few knew he also did well in singing."Today, the Wall Street Journal's China Realtime Report says Buffett has indeed recorded a New Year's greeting for China, but it doesn't include a song.Sun Media Investment Holding co-chairman Wu Zheng, the go-between for Buffett and the show's production team, tells the blog that he did plan to add a recording of Buffett singing a year ago at a charity event, but dropped that idea after Buffett objected.

column2: Eye on Commodities
column5: What's moving in commodities in Monday\xe2\x80\x99s trade: Oil: Oil prices are slightly weakeras the New Year's onslaught of commodity funds adding new long positions appears to have slowed down. Traders say the oil market is awaiting more positive news about the global economy to post gains.

column2: Option Bulls Target Inhibitex Before Buyout
column5: Inhibitex went on a crazy run last year, and the bulls looked for even more upside last week. They won't be disappointed this morning because the drug developer agreed to be purchased by Bristol-Myers Squibb for $26 a share in cash late Saturday. That's a premium of more than 160 percent.

column2: CNBC Poll: Is CES Passe?

column2: The US Chamber of Commerce on Obama's Labor Appointments

column5: Next week U.S. Chamber of Commerce chief Tom Donohue will be making the Chamber\xe2\x80\x99s big State of American Business Address. \xc2\xa0The group is turning 100 and in the past century American business has certainly transformed.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0One area unfortunately that continues to still be the same old story is the battle between big labor and companies.Recently, Mike Eastman, executive director of Labor Law Policy for the Chamber, gave us the Chamber's view of recent appointments to the National Labor Relations Board.

column2: Is Now a Good Time to Invest in Hungary?
column5: A Hungarian delegation prepares to resume talks with the International Monetary Fund this week, hoping to secure a credit lifeline while investors continue to push up the country\xe2\x80\x99s borrowing costs.

column2: Merkel and Sarkozy Put On the Sunny Face
column5: German Chancellor Angela Merkel and French President Nicolas Sarkozy put on the sunny face: Meeting in Paris, Merkel says negotiations over a new multilateral treaty to address the debt issues are going well and she reiterated that it was possible to have a signed agreement by March.The European Union merry-go-round is in full swing this week, with Merkel meeting with International Monetary Fund head Christine Lagarde tomorrow to talk about Greece, which is now in a critical stage of negotiations with bondholders over a 50 percent haircut, then meeting with Italian Prime Minister Mario Monti in Berlin on Wednesday.

column2: US Debt Is Now Equal to Economy
column5: The soaring national debt has reached a symbolic tipping point: It's now as big as the entire U.S. economy.

column2: Art Market Beats Equities for Second Year
column5: The art market defied the economic gloom to return 11 per cent to investors in 2011, outpacing stock market returns for a second consecutive year.

column2: CES: More Streaming Deals But No Synergy
column5: Even though the Consumer Electronics Showis supposed to be about electronics, in recent years it is also about the content that is served on those electronics. This year, I predict, will be the same.

column2: Juniper, Liz Claiborne, Alcoa: Trading After Hours Catalysts
column5: On Monday after the bell the Fast Money traders were taking a close look at Juniper, Liz Claiborne and Alcoa after all 3 names generated trade-able catalysts in the after market.JuniperAfter the bell, Juniper cut guidance primarily due to weaker-than-expected router demand from service providers, with developments sending shares down 4 percent in extended trade. Juniper said it now expects fourth-quarter non-GAAP earnings to be in the range of 26 cents to 28 cents a share, compared to its prior expectation of 32 cents to 36 cents a share.The company expects revenue to be $1.11 billion to $1.12 billion, compared to its prior expectation of $1.16 billion to $1.22 billion.Juniper is scheduled to report its fourth-quarter results on Jan. 26, after market close.What\xe2\x80\x99s the trade?Don\xe2\x80\x99t get spooked. The Fast Money traders say take the Juniper news in context; Acme Packet said much the same last week. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd Juniper got a little ahead of itself,\xe2\x80\x9d says Tim SeymourThey say if the news drags down the space, put rival Cisco on your radar. \xe2\x80\x9cThe chart suggests the stock is breaking out. Cisco, that\xe2\x80\x99s where I\xe2\x80\x99d want to be,\xe2\x80\x9d says Guy AdamiLiz ClaiborneShares of Liz Claiborne dropped more than 10% in extended trade after the company said earnings would come in at the low end expectations, because of negative comps and lower than expected gross margins at its Juicy Couture brand. In addition, the company said CFO Andrew Warren is leaving the company "by mutual agreement." No replacement was been named for the key position. What\xe2\x80\x99s the trade?Both Guy Adami and Karen Finerman think the pullback makes the stock a buy. \xe2\x80\x9cI think it\xe2\x80\x99s an opportunity \xe2\x80\x93 it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t seem like that big a deal,\xe2\x80\x9d Finerman says. \xe2\x80\x9cBut you\xe2\x80\x99ve got to believe they can turn around the company."Trader Mike Murphy suggests a wait and see posture. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d want to see more traction in this company before I\xe2\x80\x99d get involved.\xe2\x80\x9d(* It's worth noting that late last yearLiz Claiborne sold it's name sake brand Liz Claiborne and several others to concentrate on its Juicy Couture, Lucky Brand and Kate Spade lines. Management intends to change its name to Fifth & Pacific.)AlcoaAfter the bell, Alcoa reported a quarterly loss that met Wall Street's expectations and revenue that was above analysts' forecast, sending shares slightly higher in after-hours trading on Monday.Looking at the numbers more closely, Alcoa reported a fourth-quarter loss excluding items of 3 cents per share, down from 21 cents a share in the year-earlier period.Revenue was $5.99 billion, an increase from $5.65 billion a year ago.Revenue rose 6 percent even as the price of aluminum fell 6 percent in the fourth quarter and 18 percent in the year.What\xe2\x80\x99s the trade?Trader Mike Murphy is a buyer, but lower. \xe2\x80\x9cI think Alcoa is a great way to play the global recovery \xe2\x80\x93 I\xe2\x80\x99m a buyer under $9.\xe2\x80\x9dTim Seymour feels much the same. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a buyer around 8.50 and I\xe2\x80\x99d play up to $11.\xe2\x80\x9dGuy Adami can\xe2\x80\x99t get excited. \xe2\x80\x9cThe stock has been sideways to slightly higher since 2009.\xe2\x80\x9d______________________________________________________Got something to to say? column2: Iran Looks to Venezuela as it Scrambles for Allies
column5: Iranian President Mahmoud Ahmadinejad\xe2\x80\x99s five-day tour of Latin American countries comes at a time of rising tensions with the United States and growing international isolation. The US State Department described Iran\xe2\x80\x99s search for friends as \xe2\x80\x9cdesperate,\xe2\x80\x9d while US Treasury Secretary Timothy Geithner is expected to ratchet up the pressure in a visit to China and Japan.

column5: Citigroup expects relative outperformance in the card and payments sector although headwinds are forming, said the company\xe2\x80\x99s analysts in a research report released Monday. Analysts raised target prices on three companies in the report: American Express  to $60.00 from $58.00, MasterCard to $375.00 from $360.00 and Visa  to $104.00 from $92.00.

column2: Greece Audit Could Roil Markets Next Week
column5: An audit of Greece next week could send markets lower, so it might pay to beware of trades linked to Europe, one \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d pro said Monday. \xe2\x80\x9cNothing\xe2\x80\x99s new. We know about the risks in Europe,\xe2\x80\x9d said Larry McDonald, Newedge senior director. What is new, however, is a Jan. 16 review of Greece\xe2\x80\x99s austerity measures and tax collection rates, as well as private sector involvement.

column2: Stocks on the Move Now
column5: Shares of the following companies are showing unusual moves in Monday's trading session .Among the winners, Inhibitex is being acquired by Bristol-Myers Squibb for $2.5 billion, which represents a 163 percent premium over Friday's close.To the downside, Theravance fell on news that Relovair, a GlaxoSmithKline drug developed in the US by Theravance, had some mixed clinical results.

column2: Will Obama's New Housing Plan Be a Big Ripoff?
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: Diana Olick broke the news this morning that the Obama administration is very close to announcing a plan that would sell government-owned foreclosed properties in bulk to investors who intend to use them as rental properties. The hope is that by taking this inventory out of the sale pipeline, the program could help the broader housing market recovery more quickly.

column2: Politics Up Close and Almost Personal
column5: MANCHESTER, N. H. \xe2\x80\x94 Newt Gingrich has bright purple cheeks. Rick Santorum has a comb sticking out of his back pocket.Jon Huntsman\xe2\x80\x99s eyes are looking extremely red. Ron Paul\xe2\x80\x99s son, Rand, the senator, is much shorter in person. And Mitt Romney, according to rope-line reports, has very soft hands \xe2\x80\x94 though probably not as big as the \xe2\x80\x9cenormous hands\xe2\x80\x9d of Mr. Santorum\xe2\x80\x99s grandfather, whom the candidate invokes as a recurring parable (\xe2\x80\x9cThose hands dug freedom for me\xe2\x80\x9d). This data emerged in recent days because the presidential campaign trail remains, for a few fleeting moments before Tuesday\xe2\x80\x99s primary, up close and intimate \xe2\x80\x94 or intimate-ish. The candidate-consumer transaction remains sufficiently close-in so people can ask questions of the hopefuls and survey their mannerisms at varied events in drivable distances. Early presidential voting has become a full-on amusement spectacle in America, where political hobbyists can buy T-shirts from licensed vendors and ask would-be presidents to hold a pose with them for several seconds while Grandma tries to figure out how to get this iPhone machine to take a picture (\xe2\x80\x9cOh wait, that one didn\xe2\x80\x99t come out either, Governor\xe2\x80\x9d). It will not be like this again for a long time. After Tuesday, the campaign will enter the ether zone of media otherness, just another reality show where it will be next to impossible to approach Callista Gingrich and have her sign your copy of her children\xe2\x80\x99s book, the one with Ellis the Elephant. If campaigns are a feast, these last days before the New Hampshire primary are a smorgasbord of cotton candy, mixed nuts and red meat. What follows is a weekend sampling of the candidate\xe2\x80\x99s offerings, beginning Friday and ending Sunday. (Rick Perry, who has not been campaigning in New Hampshire, is not included.) The Paul PosseFriday, 2 p.m., Hangar Rally for Representative Ron Paul of Texas, Nashua Airport, Nashua. Before introducing candidate/Daddy Ron Paul at an airport rally, Senator Rand Paul, Republican of Kentucky, addressed a matter on everyone\xe2\x80\x99s minds: his own hair. He told of how a woman back home had recently grabbed him by his stiffly tousled mane. When he asked her what she was doing, she replied, \xe2\x80\x9cI just wanted to check to see if it was a toupee or not.\xe2\x80\x9d It\xe2\x80\x99s not clear why young Mr. Paul told this story Friday in Nashua, though perhaps to reinforce the Ron Paul campaign\xe2\x80\x99s message of authenticity (\xe2\x80\x9cHair\xe2\x80\x99s real, so\xe2\x80\x99s Dad\xe2\x80\x9d). Whatever, the crowd loved it \xe2\x80\x94 as they love everything Paul, especially Daddy Ron, who moseyed out in a professorial gray blazer a few minutes later to echoing screams. Supporters waved blue \xe2\x80\x9cRon Paul\xe2\x80\x9d placards, flags and \xe2\x80\x9cpeace\xe2\x80\x9d signs (actual printed signs, not two fingers). In an insistent drawl, Daddy Paul hits his big notes early. \xe2\x80\x9cAll I can think about is how freedom is popular,\xe2\x80\x9d he said, admiring the typical Paul Posse mix of \xe2\x80\x9cOccupy\xe2\x80\x9d types, (both pro and anti-Paul) military veterans, self-taught historians, skateboard hipsters and graying peaceniks. Mr. Paul stands mostly still at the lectern while his themes swing from his performance in Iowa to the wisdom of silver as a currency. He is the slightly doddering teacher who\xe2\x80\x99s been around forever, meanders through the hour and yet holds the class rapt. He rails against \xe2\x80\x9cthem\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x94 whom he characterizes as \xe2\x80\x9cthe people who want to run our lives, police the world and spend us into bankruptcy.\xe2\x80\x9d By a big margin, the Paul Posse is the most devoted and passionate of any candidate crowd. They are less \xe2\x80\x9csupporters\xe2\x80\x9d than followers. \xe2\x80\x9cI came even though I have a special-needs dog at home,\xe2\x80\x9d explains Jackie Casey, of Nashua. The special-needs dog \xe2\x80\x94 a Shar-Pei named Tori \xe2\x80\x94 is very old, over 100 in people years. Tori is almost blind, suffers from anxiety attacks and requires a great deal of care. And yet Ms. Casey, a former Army reservist who now works at a Dunkin\xe2\x80\x99 Donuts, would not have missed this. \xe2\x80\x9cRon Paul is the only one running for president who has not lied,\xe2\x80\x9d she said. Not like the rest of \xe2\x80\x9cthem.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: Oil Prices Could Soar 80% If Iran Shut Hormuz: Analyst
column5: If Iran were to shut down the Strait of Hormuz, a key oil transportation route where millions of barrels travel out of the Persian Gulf every day, Brent crude would surge to between $150 and $200 a barrel, according to an oil analyst with Societe Generale.\xe2\x80\x9cWe believe it would be relatively easy for Iran to shut down the Straits of Hormuz,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote Michael Wittner, in a report late Friday to clients. \xe2\x80\x9cA credible threat from missiles, mines, or fast attack boats is all it would take for tanker insurers to stop coverage, which would halt tanker traffic. However, we believe that Iran would not be able to keep the Straits shut for longer than two weeks, due to a US-led military response.\xe2\x80\x9dHowever, the analyst puts this aggressive action as a low probability event. The more likely scenario is an embargo imposed by the European Union, accompanied by U.S. pressure on other countries to do the same, which could still send Brent prices to the $125 to $150 range. Brent was trading above $112 a barrel on Monday.\xe2\x80\x9cAnEU embargo is considered likely, especially after the EU reached an agreement in principle on an embargo on January 4th,\xe2\x80\x9d wrote the analyst. \xe2\x80\x9cWhen it is announced, depending on the timing and details, we may revise our base case oil price forecast upward.\xe2\x80\x9dMore than 15 million barrels a day flow through the strait, making it one of the most (if not THE most) important points for oil delivery in the world. Its North coast is made up of Iran, which recently announced that it has started uranium enrichment at one of its Nuclear plants, further inviting sanctions by Western nations.Traders see the European embargo and the way Iran responds to it as keeping a bottom under oil prices for much of 2012.\xe2\x80\x9cAt no point during the year would I suggest going home short crude,\xe2\x80\x9d said David Greenberg, president of Greenberg Capital and former member of the NYMEX board. \xe2\x80\x9cWe could easily open $25 higher on the Brent market\xe2\x80\x9d following a drastic move by Iran.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0 For the best market insight, catch 'Fast Money' each night at 5pm ET, and the \xe2\x80\x98Halftime Report\xe2\x80\x99 each afternoon at 12:00 ET on CNBC. column2: After Another 52-Week High, Can Apple Just Keep Climbing?
column5: On Monday the Fast gang took a long hard look at Apple , after the stock made a new all time high and Goldman issued a high profile upgrade.Influential Goldman analyst Bill Shoppe raised his price target to $550 from $520 suggesting that \xe2\x80\x9cseveral key catalysts,\xe2\x80\x9d including increased iPhone sales, should help the stock in 2012.Meanwhile Apple touched another new all-time high after rivals introduced something PC World called \xe2\x80\x98rip-offs\xe2\x80\x99 of Apple\xe2\x80\x99s MacBook Air at the or CES. Investors took the new devices as a sign that Apple remained the gadget maker to beat. (Apple does not participate in the show.)How should you trade Apple now?Trader Pete Najarian is bullish. He says numbers continue to be impressive and he expects the company to \xe2\x80\x98fire on all cylinders\xe2\x80\x99 for quite some time to come.Trader Brian Kelly agrees though at current levels he suggests waiting for a pullback. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m a buyer but a little lower," he says, "the stock feels a little frothy.\xe2\x80\x9dTrader Josh Brown says \xe2\x80\x9cstick with it if you\xe2\x80\x99re long but, at these levels, I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t pile in for a new buy, either.\xe2\x80\x9dAnd if you\xe2\x80\x99re a nimble pro who\xe2\x80\x99s thinking about a short position the Fast traders have some advice \xe2\x80\x93 don\xe2\x80\x99t do it. They all feel Apple has so much momentum that to go short is to do so at your own peril.

column2: Bank Deposits at ECB Hit New High, Seen Climbing
column5: Commercial banks' overnight deposits at the European Central Bank hit a new record high of 464 billion euros, data showed on Monday, and traders said they could hit half a trillion euros by next week.

column2: Six in Ten Hedge Funds Lost Money in 2011
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: It\xe2\x80\x99s not just the big Wall Street firms that are having dismal years and slashing bonuses.Nearly 60% of hedge funds lost money in 2011, according to preliminary data from the HedgeFund Intelligence Database.Asia-based funds suffered the worst performance, declining 5.70 percent, according to the database. Japan\xe2\x80\x99s devastating tsunami and nuclear disaster might have contributed to this. European funds declined 2.45 percent. US funds lost just 0.50 percent. Fund of funds lost 5.04 percent.

column2: Government Set to Sell Foreclosures in Bulk
column5: The Obama administration, in conjunction with federal regulators and led by the overseer of Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, is very close to announcing a pilot program to sell government-owned foreclosures in bulk to investors as rentals, according to administration officials.There currently are about a quarter of a million foreclosed properties on the books of Fannie Mae, Freddie Mac, and the Federal Housing Administration (FHA), and millions more are coming. The foreclosure processing delays of last year created a mammoth backlog of properties yet to be processed, which are just now being re-started. One of the initiatives of this program is for the federal government to be in the position to mitigate and manage any new wave of foreclosures, sources say. Late-stage delinquencies still in the pipeline number close to two million, according to a new report from Lender Processing Services. Foreclosure starts outnumber foreclosure sales by two to one and "the trend toward fewer loans becoming delinquent, which dominated 2010 and the first quarter of 2011, appears to have halted," according to LPS.

column2: First 5 Trading Days: An Early Harbinger
column5: According to the Stock Trader\xe2\x80\x99s Almanac, there have been 38 instances since 1950 when the market was up during the first five days of the years. During those occurrences, the market followed with a full-year gain 87 percent of the time, producing an average gain of 13.9 percent.\xc2\xa0Will history repeat itself? In the past five trading session, the S&P 500  is up 1.8 percent.Indeed, the gains mark the best first five days since 2010, when the index was up 2.7 percent during the period. The start of that year was a telling sign for what was to come as the S&P finished 2010 with significant increases, up 23.5 percent.

column2: Auto Sales Up, So Is CEO Enthusiasm
column5: Is the U.S. auto industry back in the driver's seat? Many executives of the biggest car makers seem to think so. Here is a roundup of the comments some of them made to CNBC Monday from the Detroit Auto Show.Chrysler CEO Sergio Marchionne

column2: Euro Zone Must 'Stick Together': Analyst
column5: There is a 'low probability' that the euro zone will break up because the costs to debtors and creditors are just too large, Philip Poole, Global Head of Macro and Investment Strategy at HSBC Global Asset Management told CNBC Monday.

column2: Big Three Newscasts Are Changing the State of Play
column5: There was a time when each of the Big Three nightly newscasts on American television tended to open with the same story \xe2\x80\x94 the latest campaign speech, a new government study or perhaps a big snowstorm. That time is gone.

column2: Santander Sells Assets Instead of Capital-Raising
column5: Santander says "no way" to capital raising; sells assets instead. Spanish bank Santander announced it has reached the 9 percent capital ratio required by the European Banking Authority, a full 6 months ahead of the June 2012 deadline. It was previously announced there was a shortfall of some 15.3 billion euros.

column2: Are Charts Forecasting Drops In Tiffany, Coach?
column5: Recent Tiffany and Coach stock-price trends suggest to \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d technical analyst Abigail Doolittle that share prices are heading south for both companies. \xe2\x80\x9cI suspect that relative to what\xe2\x80\x99s going on here with Tiffany and potential weakness ahead, it\xe2\x80\x99s not so much about the holiday sales in the past, but more about this company\xe2\x80\x99s exposure to the international scene,\xe2\x80\x9d the Peak Theories Research analyst said Monday. \xe2\x80\x9cMore than 50 percent of their sales are global.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: PAC Ads to Attack Romney as Predatory Capitalist
column5: MANCHESTER, N.H. \xe2\x80\x94 Thanks to a $5 million donation from a wealthy casino owner, a group supporting Newt Gingrich plans to place advertisements in South Carolina this week attacking Mitt Romney as a predatory capitalist who destroyed jobs and communities, a full-scale Republican assault on Mr. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s business background.The advertisements, a counterpunch to a campaign waged against Mr. Gingrich by a group backing Mr. Romney, will be built on excerpts from a scathing movie about Bain Capital, the private equity firm Mr. Romney once ran. The movie, financed by a Republican operative opposed to Mr. Romney, includes emotional interviews with people who lost jobs at companies that Bain bought and later sold. \xe2\x80\x9cWe had to load up the U-Haul because we done lost our home,\xe2\x80\x9d one woman says. Democrats have signaled that they intend to make Mr. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s history at Bain a central part of their case against him if he wins the Republican nomination. But Bain has also emerged as an issue in the Republican primary, despite the party\xe2\x80\x99s free market stance and business-friendly policies, reflecting the depth of public anger about the economy. At an appearance here on Sunday, Mr. Gingrich suggested that Bain\xe2\x80\x99s approach was to carry out \xe2\x80\x9cclever legal ways to loot a company.\xe2\x80\x9d But the planned advertisements appear to be intended to elevate the subject to a new level as Mr. Gingrich and the other Republican contenders begin to run out of time to slow Mr. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s progress toward the nomination. They are the latest example of how \xe2\x80\x9csuper PACs\xe2\x80\x9d are carrying out attacks in sync with their preferred candidates and in the process helping to reshape the presidential race. Super PACs can raise unlimited amounts of money but are barred from coordinating with the campaigns they are supporting. The Bain-centered campaign strikes at the heart of Mr. Romney\xe2\x80\x99s argument for his qualifications as president \xe2\x80\x94 that as a successful executive in the private sector, he learned how to create jobs \xe2\x80\x94 and advances an argument that President Obama\xe2\x80\x99s re-election campaign has signaled it will employ aggressively against Mr. Romney. \xe2\x80\x9cHis business success comes from raiding and destroying businesses \xe2\x80\x94 putting people out of work, stealing their health care,\xe2\x80\x9d said Rick Tyler, a senior adviser to the pro-Gingrich super PAC, Winning Our Future, which recently bought the film, \xe2\x80\x9cKing of Bain: When Mitt Romney Came to Town,\xe2\x80\x9d after groups backing two other Republican candidates passed up opportunities to use it.

column2: PCs and Mobile Phones Are This Year's Gadget Industry Stars
column5: Two years ago, 3D TV commanded center stage at the annual . Last year, it was tablets. This year, while both of those product groups will still be shown in force, it looks like the PC is ready to make a comeback.

column2: One-on-One With JPMorgan's Dimon
column5: At the 30th Annual JPMorgan Healthcare Conference in San Francisco, Chairman & CEO Jamie Dimon outlined his views on the economy, Europe and banking stress tests for 2012 in a CNBC Exclusive with Maria Bartiromo.

column2: Options Investors Think Brocade Deal Imminent
column5: If options activity reflects market sentiment, then big money pros think Brocade is close to a deal.According to Options pro Scott Nations, call buying was through the roof on Monday with professional investors making upside bets. \xe2\x80\x9cVolume was about 8 times normal. And (institutional investors) were really reaching to buy those calls,\xe2\x80\x9d he says.And Nations believes the activity makes sense. Chatter on the floor suggests IBM and Oracle might be potential bidders. \xe2\x80\x9cAnd if big companies want to own something with a less than $3 billion market cap, a bidding war could ensue,\xe2\x80\x9d speculates Nations.Nations may be all fired up over the potential of a bidding war, but not trader Karen Finerman. She thinks there are better places to put money to work. \xe2\x80\x9cIt sounds like they\xe2\x80\x99re open to a sale \xe2\x80\x93 but I wouldn\xe2\x80\x99t get involved.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: RBS Executive in Line for $6.1 Million Bonus
column5: The head of Royal Bank of Scotland\xe2\x80\x99s embattled investment bank is in line to receive a special bonus this year of more than $6.1 million, an award that will be contentious given the government\xe2\x80\x99s vow to crack down on excessive executive pay.

column2: Christie Responds to Hecklers Jersey-style
column5: EXETER, N.H. \xe2\x80\x94 Protesters hassled both Mitt Romney and Chris Christie at a joint event. Their reactions were a little different.As hecklers shouted "Mitt kills jobs," Romney \xe2\x80\x94 the front-runner in Tuesday's New Hampshire primary \xe2\x80\x94 took a diplomatic approach: "I'm happy to have you guys express your views. ... Next time do it with more courtesy."Later Sunday night, when protesters began shouting "Christie kills jobs," the New Jersey governor was not so diplomatic."Really?" Christie said. "Something may go down tonight but it's not going to be jobs, sweetheart."

column2: Sony's Stringer: \xe2\x80\x98Decks Are Cleared\xe2\x80\x99
column5: Shares of Sony have lost half its value in the past year. The company was hit on all fronts, drop in stock price, market share and natural disasters. Maria Bartiromo spoke exclusively with CEO Howard Stringer about all these issues and about speculation of management changes at Sony. On Friday, the Nikkei Business Daily reported that Kazuo Hirai will take over as Sony President, leaving Stringer as Chairman and CEO. Stringer responded, \xe2\x80\x9cIt hasn't been approved yet. The succession planning in that arena is my responsibility and, as you know, I started as Chairman and CEO, and I'm simply returning to that.\xe2\x80\x9d When Maria pushed Stringer if this will take in effect in April, Stringer said \xe2\x80\x9cwe need a board meeting for that.\xe2\x80\x9d \xe2\x80\x9cGlass Half Empty, Glass Half Full" Scenario 2011 was a tough year for Sony with the stock down 50%. Natural disasters struck; Japan\xe2\x80\x99s earthquake and floods in Thailand had a huge impact on Sony\xe2\x80\x99s suppliers. Sony also lost ground to competitors like Samsung and Panasonic on the TV front. Stringer sees it as \xe2\x80\x9cglass half empty, glass half full\xe2\x80\x9d scenario. Stringer said Sony is still facing the reality of shortages. But now, \xe2\x80\x9ceverything's cleared, the decks are cleared,\xe2\x80\x9d Stringer said. \xe2\x80\x9cWe've done the Sony-Ericsson deal. We've moved away from the Samsung joint venture. So we think we're now ready to concentrate on a new year. Unless meteorites shower on us, I think we'll be back in business again, and we're rather looking forward to it. This is kind of a kickoff to a brand-new year,\xe2\x80\x9d Stringer added.

column2: US Economy in 'Mild Recovery': JPMorgan's Dimon
column5: The U.S. is in a "mild recovery" that is "broad and strengthening," JPMorgan Chase CEO Jamie Dimon told CNBC Monday.

column2: UK Leaves Door Open for IMF Cash
column5: David Cameron has left open the door to Britain giving billions of pounds of new support to the International Monetary Fund \xe2\x80\x93 and indirectly to ailing members of the euro zone \xe2\x80\x93 in a move likely to infuriate euroskeptic MPs in his own Conservative party.

column2: Guy Adami: Alkermes a \xe2\x80\x98No-Play\xe2\x80\x99 at This Level
column5: Biotech firm Alkermes expects FDA approval for its new diabetes drug this month, but that might not be enough to make the stock worth buying, \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d pro Guy Adami said Monday. \xe2\x80\x9cIf you look at the charts since July, it\xe2\x80\x99s been in this very defined channel from $18 on the high end down to $14. It\xe2\x80\x99s held $14 now three times over the last seven or eight months, give or take,\xe2\x80\x9d he said. \xe2\x80\x9cAt $17\xc2\xbd we\xe2\x80\x99re toward the upper end of the range here. I\xe2\x80\x99m not saying you should short it, but if you\xe2\x80\x99ve caught this move, trade this stock around these levels. I would think you look for a sell-off, maybe buy it back around the $15 level. Otherwise, here it\xe2\x80\x99s a no-play.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: Your First Move For Tuesday January 10th
column5: Here\xe2\x80\x99s our Fast Money Final Trade. Our gang gives you tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s best trades, right now.Tim Seymour suggests long Vimpel Com. \xe2\x80\x9cStay in this trade,\xe2\x80\x9d he says.Guy Adami recommends longVisa. \xe2\x80\x9c I\xe2\x80\x99d continue to stay with that one.\xe2\x80\x9dKaren Finerman says \xe2\x80\x9cit\xe2\x80\x99s time to reload in Children\xe2\x80\x99s Place.\xe2\x80\x9dMike Murphy thinks Tyco is a buy.

column2: Why Earnings May Be Better Than All the Dire Forecasts
column5: Chief executives and analysts have lowered expectations by so much for earnings reporting season, stocks may continue their 2012 gains as results come in higher than expected.

column2: Earnings Season: No Implosion Coming
column5: Earnings: gimme a break. The way the talk is, you'd think there is going to be some kind of titanic implosion of earnings coming. Balderdash. We are simply reverting to the mean after a period of extraordinary earnings growth following the collapse of the global economy in 2008. Doubt me? Earnings collapsed in 2008. We had eight long quarters of negative earnings growth from Q4 2007 through Q3 2009!

column2: Emerging Markets Could Soar 30% in 2012: Strategist
column5: Following a dismal 2011, emerging markets could see up to a 30 percent gain this year, assuming the sovereign debt crisis in the euro zone is kept at bay, according to Geoffrey Dennis, managing director at Citi.

column2: How to Handicap a European Central Bank Rate Cut
column5: The European Central Bank is meeting on Thursday amid a wave of grim economic data. Here's one expert's take on what will happen.The Europeans may not be resolving their crisis, but it's sure not for lack of talking about it.  and the question on investors' minds is whether they might at least cut interest rates to spur the sluggish euro zone economy.Not likely, says Michael Plavnik, head of the short-term interest rate desk at Citigroup .

column2: Why Weak Earnings Outlook Could Actually Help Stocks
column5: A downbeat earnings season forecast could be just the remedy the stock market needs to break out of its winter doldrums, at least if history holds true.

column2: Jamie Dimon: JP Morgan Can Stay Solvent Longer Than Europe Can Stay Irrational
column3: Net Net: Promoting innovation and managing change
column5: Jamie Dimon told Maria Bartiromo yesterday that he wouldn't mind losing $5 billion in Europe so long as he gets to keep doing business there for the next 100 years.In an interview during Closing Bell, Dimon said his bank had about $15 billion in exposure. But the risks were worth taking to stay in the business of helping clients do business in Europe.

column2: Earnings Season: Shall We Dance?
column5: There is a bit of a dance that goes on into the early days of earnings season. This year the dance more tense than usual.

column2: Sotheby's Sees Big Call Activity
column5: On a day where Tiffany shares are getting pummeled, one company that also caters to the uber rich is seeing some pretty impressive price action: Sotheby\xe2\x80\x99s. The stock  is surging 8% today, and call activity suggest options traders see more fun to come. Call activity is over seven times its daily average volume, with over three thousand of the April 35-strike calls trading hands at an average price of $1.90 each, a trade that isn\xe2\x80\x99t profitable unless BID shares hit $36.90 by April, a 15% increase. According to some market participants, the move can be attributed to a press release the company put out this morning detailing its February impressionist auction. According to the release, the sale is expected to bring in \xc2\xa378 million pounds, and 8% increase from the previous year. That would be a welcome change for the auction giant, which has seen sales of impressionist paintings in Europe suffer due to the continent\xe2\x80\x99s growing debt crisis. (According to those in the know, and I claim not to be one, Europeans just love Gustav Klimt). \xe2\x80\x9cThat\xe2\x80\x99s a positive surprise that London would see so much supply come to market in the impressionist category,\xe2\x80\x9d said Wedbush Securities Rommel Dionisio (Outperform). \xe2\x80\x9cEurope\xe2\x80\x99s been the weak area in the art market.\xe2\x80\x9d Watch Options Actionon CNBC Fridays 5:00pm ET, Saturdays at\xc2\xa0 6a ET and on Sundays at\xc2\xa0 6a ETQuestions, comments send them to us at: optionsaction@cnbc.com

column2: Your First Move For Wednesday January 11th
column5: Here\xe2\x80\x99s our Fast Money Final Trade. Our gang gives you tomorrow\xe2\x80\x99s best trades, right now.Tim Seymour suggests long Vimpel-Com as a bullish bet on Russian cellular.Karen Finerman recommends long Mastercard . \xe2\x80\x9cIt\xe2\x80\x99s come in quite a bit and I like it here,\xe2\x80\x9d she says. Joe Terranova prefers long State Street in the financial sector.Dan Nathan says if you\xe2\x80\x99re cautiously bullish consider a stock replacement strategy. \xe2\x80\x9cSell your stock and buy some calls,\xe2\x80\x9d he says.

column2: Pros Mixed On Corning\xe2\x80\x99s Gorilla Glass 2 Outlook
column5: Corning CEO Wendell Weeks showed off the company\xe2\x80\x99s new, thinner Gorilla Glass 2 on Tuesday, but the \xe2\x80\x9cFast Money\xe2\x80\x9d experts weren\xe2\x80\x99t unanimously swayed on the stock\xe2\x80\x99s prospects for 2012. \xe2\x80\x9cWe\xe2\x80\x99ve reinvented the product so you can be 20 percent thinner with the same legendary strength,\xe2\x80\x9d Weeks said in a demonstration of . Maker of high-strength touch screens for smartphones, tablets, TVs and PCs, Corning introduced its new product at .

column2: Cramer Suggests SandRidge Spinoff
column5: Cramer on Monday suggested viewers participate in an upcoming offering from SandRidge Energy, namely SandRidge Mississippian Trust II, which will soon trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol SDR.The \xe2\x80\x9cMad Money\xe2\x80\x9d host likes the deal because it\xe2\x80\x99s going to be backed by the hydrocarbons from both the producing wells and others in development on 53,000 net acres in a proven oil formation in Northern Oklahoma and Kansas. Cramer said another reason to like the deal is because CEO Tom Ward has a strong track record of success.If the past is any indicator, Cramer thinks this deal will offer good distribution and surge to a premium immediately upon its first trade. He\xe2\x80\x99s a buyer.Call Cramer: 1-800-743-CNBCQuestions for Cramer? Questions, comments, suggestions for the Mad Money website? madcap@cnbc.com

column2: Strength In Tech, Financials Means Rally
column5: Should the technology and financial sectors see continued strength, Cramer on Monday said the overall stock market could rally. Given a few indicators, it seems that could very well happen, too.Although both tech and financials were among the worst laggards for the latter half of 2011, the two sectors have been acting like leaders in 2012. Nevertheless, nobody expects much from either and the average analyst on Wall Street has incredibly low expectations for tech and financial companies, not including Apple , U.S. Bancorp  and Wells Fargo . The expectations are so low for these two sectors that Cramer thinks most companies will actually be able to beat on earnings.It would be hard for stocks to rally without strength in the tech and financial space. After all, tech is the biggest component of the S&P 500 , accounting for roughly 17.5 percent of the index. The banks, a major part of the financial sector, make up around 12.4 percent of the S&P.So what\xe2\x80\x99s the bottom line?\xe2\x80\x9cThe biggest surprise of 2012 could be that the financials, the most hated group out there, can actually soar,\xe2\x80\x9d Cramer said. \xe2\x80\x9cIf that happens, the leaders, like USB and Wells Fargo can really romp, particularly now that the largest market cap bank, and the de facto winner, is Wells.\xe2\x80\x9cApple and Wells Fargo, they are the purloined letters of this market, hidden right in plain sight and ready for the grabbing.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: Moody's Upgrade Validates Macy's Strategy: CEO
column5: Moody's upgrade of Macy's credit ratings to investment grade validates the company's business strategy, CEO Terry Lundgren told CNBC.

column2: UniCredit\xe2\x80\x99s Share Offering Is Poor Omen in Europe
column5: UniCredit, Italy\xe2\x80\x99s largest bank, is undergoing a trial by fire in the stock market, underscoring the challenges that European banks face in trying to right themselves.

column2: Breakout: S&P 500\xe2\x80\x99s Highest Close Since July Could Fuel More Buying
column5: The S&P 500 closed above its closing high hit last October, a technical breakout that could spark more buying, chart analysts and traders said. How much buying, though, is subject to debate.It could go \xe2\x80\x9ca lot higher,\xe2\x80\x9d said Dennis Gartman, whose The Gartman Letter is usually filled with analysis of charts. \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99d like to see a bit more volume, but I\xe2\x80\x99ll take what I can get.\xe2\x80\x9dNow at the highest since July, the benchmark leaves behind a 2 \xc2\xbd month trading range it was trapped in as concerns about the European financial crisis continued to push it down. The market is pricing in an improvement in the U.S. economy and good results in the upcoming earnings season, traders said.\xe2\x80\x9cWe are probably looking at new all-time highs on the S&P 500 by the end of the year,\xe2\x80\x9d said Adam Grimes, chief investment officer for Waverly Advisors. \xe2\x80\x9cThere is significant technical support and justification for such a rally, and we are now in area that justifies a more aggressive stance on risk, as opposed to our hands-off attitude of the past several months.\xe2\x80\x9dAlcoa, the first Dow Jones Industrial Average member to report 4th quarter results, kicked of the earnings season right, gaining after it predicted strong aluminum demand this year. The PowerShares QQQ Trust \xc2\xa0, which tracks the tech-heavy Nasdaq-100 Index, is about 1 percent from breaking out to a new high. A breakout by the more volatile security could mark a true return to the risk trade.\xe2\x80\x9cLook at the QQQ's for an animal spirits gauge,\xe2\x80\x9d said Josh Brown, a trader with Fusion Analytics and author of the popular  blog. \xe2\x80\x9cThe more times it tries to break through, the bigger the eventual breakout. If it breaks $59 to $60, this is a new 11-year high and the whole market will go crazy.\xe2\x80\x9d ---------------------------------------------------------------------NEW SLIDESHOW: The Biggest Momentum Stocks of 2011: Buy or Sell?---------------------------------------------------------------------For the best market insight, catch 'Fast Money' each night at 5pm ET, and the \xe2\x80\x98Halftime Report\xe2\x80\x99 each afternoon at 12:00 ET on CNBC. column2: Playing a Potential Housing Resurgence
column5: There may soon be a housing resurgence, Cramer said Monday, at least if bullish comments from prominent businessmen and recent data are any indicator.Jack Welch joined the group of notable businessmen, who think housing could soon turn around. The former CEO of General Electric made bullish comments on housing while appearing on CNBC Monday. Meanwhile, pending home sales recently hit its highest level in 19 months. The National Association of Realtors\xe2\x80\x99 existing home sales index rose by 7.3 percent from October to November while experts had only expected an increase of just 1 percent.To play this potential housing resurgence, Cramer suggests Weyerhaeuser. The second-largest owner of timberland in the United States, Cramer said it\xe2\x80\x99s more profitable and productive than its competitors. Cramer said its successes are, in a part, due to its fabulous management team.The timber company\xe2\x80\x99s stock sports a 3.2 percent dividend yield. It\xe2\x80\x99s cheap, too, trading at a 30 percent discount to its net asset value. He recommends investors consider buying shares at current levels because by the time housing does actually turn around, it may be too late.When this story was published, Cramer\xe2\x80\x99s charitable trust owned Weyerhaeuser and General Electric owns 49 percent of NBCUniversal, which operates CNBC.Call Cramer: 1-800-743-CNBCQuestions for Cramer? Questions, comments, suggestions for the Mad Money website? madcap@cnbc.com

column2: Global Stocks Up on China, France, Alcoa
column5: Global stocks up on China, France, Alcoa. Green everywhere this morning: 1) China rallied for a second day as December exports and imports posted their weakest growth in more than 2 years; that's not good, but traders seem to be expecting more easing of bank lending restrictions. The Shanghai Index up 2.7 percent. 2) Ratings agency Fitch said it would not downgrade France's credit rating in 2012. French banks like BNP Paribas up 6 percent in Europe. 3) Alcoa: the sky didn't fall. Commodity stocks are up 3 to 6 percent, Alcoa  up 2 percent because results were mostly in line with lowered expectations, including a restructuring charge.

column2: Dollar-Reserve Dumping? Not So Much
column5: Funny what a European debt crisis can do to the appeal of the dollar.It wasn't so long ago that experts were predicting that the dollar would soon cease to be a major reserve currency. Well, don't hold your breath. Data released at the very end of 2011 show that dollar reserves were maintaining at roughly 61.7 percent of all reserves at the end of the third quarter, while euro  reserves declined by about 0.9 percent in the first nine months of 2011, and 1.5 percent since the beginning of the debt crisis. Now, the dollar isn't exactly winning popularity contests. While Switzerland and Japan added to their dollar holdings, developing countries shed dollars, according to an analysis by Alan Ruskin, global head of G10 FX strategy at Deutsche Bank.Still, he says, other major currencies like the yen  have been unable to break into the reserve-currency big leagues, making reserves increasingly the province of the dollar and the euro. And the overall trend right now, he says, "fits with thoughts that the glacial reduction in the USD reserve status has flattened out, while the EUR\xe2\x80\x99s reserve share has peaked, and more tentatively taken over a \xe2\x80\x98glacial\xe2\x80\x99 decline trend from the USD, that has potential to accelerate."Ruskin doesn't see demand for euro reserves picking up until there are clear signs of resolution of the debt crisis.----------------------------CURRENCY FUTURESTune In: CNBC's "Money in Motion Currency Trading" airs on Fridays at 5:30pm and repeats on Saturdays at 7pm.
