column2: Commentary: Shaping a New Communications Model - Silence is Golden
column5: It might sound heretical for a leader of a communications firm to suggest it, but lately I\xe2\x80\x99ve been thinking that a lot of big brands and companies should take a vow of silence.Not forever, but at key moments in time. In this era of radical transparency, rather than trying to explain what you\xe2\x80\x99re doing to fix a problem or poor performance or disappointing service, put all of that energy into fixing it first. Let people see the difference, then call in the communicators to amplify the actions you\xe2\x80\x99ve taken. Fortunately I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen more and more companies coming to this realization: actions trump words and actions must precede words to have credibility. The theme this week at the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in Davos, Switzerland, is \xe2\x80\x9cThe Great Transformation: Shaping New Models.\xe2\x80\x9d The delegates at the meeting will discuss new models for multi-stakeholder action on everything from sustainability to world peace. Moving closer to home, I hope that corporate leaders and those of us in communications can agree that our best model is one that puts action on the front end of the process, followed by communication with customers inviting them to experience again the service or product and then use communications to amplify that experience and build advocacy at scale. Particularly at a time of high unemployment and economic divides, the public has little to no patience for companies that try to talk their way out of a mess before taking real action. It\xe2\x80\x99s time to do the right thing and then, with humility, communicate about it.

column2: Recent CAT Buyers Got It Wrong: Fast Pros
column5: With 4th quarter profit soaring more than 60%, should you pile into Caterpillar and other global growth trades? Not so fast.Considering CAT shares are up more than 20% for just this month, at least some investors like what they see from CAT. But Fast Money traders Steve Cortes and Mike Murphy think recent buyers are misguided.Largely gains in Caterpillar have been interpreted as a sign the global growth trade remains robust. But Cortes says that may not be the case. InCaterpillar's earningsreport, released on Thursday, they said some of the buying was generated by customers who had previously put off purchases until they absolutely had to replace their aging equipment. Cortes also didn\xe2\x80\x99t find all of CATs outlook to be terribly bullish.-----------------------------------------------------------NEW SLIDESHOW: The Top Secrets of Pro Traders-----------------------------------------------------------The company warned that while Europe's economic crisis probably won't trigger a global recession, economic growth in eurozone counties probably won't improve until the second half of this year.And outside CAT, Cortes points to the recent S&P gains of only 10 points despite blockbuster Apple earnings and a Fed statement in which the central bank promised to keep rates 'lower for longer.\xe2\x80\x99If the market was about to embrace risk in a big way, he argues the S&P would be much higher.Although Cortes concedes the Fed move could trigger a rotation, he expects money to chase yield. \xe2\x80\x9cThe Fed will force investors into defensive stocks,\xe2\x80\x9d he says, \xe2\x80\x9cmoney will go into tobacco and utilities but not global growth names.\xe2\x80\x9d

column2: Stock Market Breakout Unlikely, Chart Patterns Not Bullish: Traders
column5: If chart patterns in the Dow  and S&P are to be believed, stocks will either go sideways or lower, but higher is unlikely. So says top Oppeneheimer technical analyst Carter Worth. It\xe2\x80\x99s not so much where the market is \xe2\x80\x93 but how we got here. \xe2\x80\x9cHad we gotten here in a slow steady line it would be one thing, but the fits and starts of the last 6 months scared off retail investors,\xe2\x80\x9d observes Karen Finerman.Though Finerman is a value investor, it turns out her analysis aligns with charts.\xe2\x80\x9cWe had an epic plunge in mid 2011 and now we\xe2\x80\x99ve recovered all that lost ground,\xe2\x80\x9d explains Worth. -----------------------------------------------------------NEW SLIDESHOW: The Top Secrets of Pro Traders-----------------------------------------------------------\xe2\x80\x9cWhen you get back to the level from which you sold off, people who were hurt badly by the decline -- and have now seen that money returned to them -- are inclined to sell. That\xe2\x80\x99s human nature.\xe2\x80\x9dAlso, fearing resistance, savvy investors who bought around the lows lock in profits."Because of these tendencies, the market almost never breaks out on the first test of the high. The probability is sideways or some kind of backing away,\xe2\x80\x9d says Worth. The likelihood that the rally continues is slight.

column2: Bank of America Short Interest Lowest Since August
column5: In the middle of January, Bank of America's short interest ratio fell to its lowest level since Aug. 31, according to data from Bloomberg. Bank of America's short interest ratio fell to 0.56 percent as of the Jan. 13 close, the most recent date for which short interest data is available. The New York Stock Exchange releases data on short interest twice a month. The 0.56 percent ratio compares to a ratio of 0.73 percent on Dec. 30.
